filename: A. D’ascenzo and M. D’emidio - 2023 - Top-k Distance Queries on Large Time-Evolving Graphs.pdf
filepath: /Users/v/solomonresearch/blockchain sna litrev/PDFs/A. D’ascenzo and M. D’emidio - 2023 - Top-k Distance Queries on Large Time-Evolving Graphs.pdf
abstract_text:
Fast extraction of top-k distances from graph data is a primitive of paramount importance in
the fields of data mining, network analytics and machine learning, where ranked distances are exploited
for several purposes (e.g. link prediction or network classification). While investigation on computational
methods to address this retrieval task for regularly sized, static inputs has been extensive, much less is known
when managed graphs are massive,...
abstract_supported_sentences:
"Fast extraction of top-k distances from graph data is a primitive of paramount importance in the fields of data mining, network analytics and machine learning"
"While investigation on computational methods to address this retrieval task for regularly sized, static inputs has been extensive, much less is known when managed graphs are massive"
"We assess the scalability and effectiveness of our method through extensive experimentation on both real-world and artificial graph datasets"
abstract_unsupported_claims: None found - all claims are well supported by the paper content
relevant_body_sentences:
"dyn-kpll is extremely fast in updating indexes even for the largest inputs and values of k, and outperforms the recomputation from scratch by k-pll in all experimental trials by orders of magnitude" (p.11)
"indexes updated via dyn-kpll preserve the nice properties of k-2-Hop Covers in terms of compactness (i.e. index size), which is reflected into extremely small average query times" (p.12)
"our experimentation provides strong evidences that maintaining k-2-Hop Covers via dyn-kpll is the most practical framework to deal with top-k distance queries when large graphs subject to incremental updates have to be managed" (p.13)

filename: Abbasi et al. - 2021 - The adoption of cryptocurrency as a disruptive force Deep learning-based dual stage structural equa.pdf
filepath: /Users/v/solomonresearch/blockchain sna litrev/PDFs/Abbasi et al. - 2021 - The adoption of cryptocurrency as a disruptive force Deep learning-based dual stage structural equa.pdf
findings:
- Trust is the strongest predictor of cryptocurrency adoption intention (p.17, p.19)
- Performance expectancy, price value, effort expectancy and personal innovativeness have positive influence on adoption intention (p.19)
- Deep learning dual-stage PLS-SEM & ANN analysis showed better predictive power (74%) compared to PLS-SEM alone (68.2%) (p.16)
- Personal innovativeness positively moderates relationship between performance expectancy and price value (p.14)
- Social influence, facilitating conditions and hedonic motivation showed insignificant effects on adoption intention (p.17-18)
gaps:
- Limited research on cryptocurrency adoption in emerging markets like Malaysia (p.2)
- Lack of studies focusing on individual-level adoption factors (p.2)
- Need for deep learning approaches vs shallow neural networks in technology adoption research (p.3)
- Limited understanding of non-linear relationships in adoption models (p.19)
methodologies:
- Deep learning-based dual stage PLS-SEM & ANN analysis (p.11)
- Online survey with 314 valid responses (p.9)
- UTAUT2 theoretical framework extended with trust and personal innovativeness (p.4-8)
- Two-hidden layer deep ANN architecture (p.15)
- PLS-SEM for linear relationships and ANN for non-linear relationships (p.11)
limitations:
- Cross-sectional study unable to validate behavior changes over time (p.21)
- Limited to Malaysian context, cannot be generalized (p.21)
- Post-adoption behavior not examined (p.21)
- No comparison between single layer and multi-layer neural networks (p.21)
abstract_supported_sentences:
- "The purpose of the study is to examine whether the application of deep learning-based dual-stage PLS-SEM & ANN analysis enable better in-depth research results"
- "Trust proved to be the strongest predictor in driving user intention"
- "The Unified Theory of Acceptance and Use of Technology 2 (UTAUT2) model were extended with the inclusion of trust and personnel innovativeness"
abstract_unsupported_claims:
- Abstract does not acknowledge study limitations
- Claim about "enormous increase in cryptocurrency markets" not quantified in paper
relevant_body_sentences:
"Trust, in this study, has proved to be the most potent effect in finding the intention to adopt cryptocurrency" (p.19)
"The findings of non-linear associations are a breakthrough in the extant literature of cryptocurrency-related literature" (p.20)
"Results depict that trust, performance expectancy, price value, effort expectancy and personal innovativeness have a positive influence on user's behavioural intention to adopt cryptocurrency" (p.21)

filename: Agarwal et al. - 2021 - Detecting malicious accounts in permissionless blockchains using temporal graph properties.pdf
filepath: /Users/v/solomonresearch/blockchain sna litrev/PDFs/Agarwal et al. - 2021 - Detecting malicious accounts in permissionless blockchains using temporal graph properties.pdf
abstract_text:
Directed Graph based models of a blockchain that capture accounts as nodes and 
transactions as edges, evolve over time. This temporal nature of a blockchain model 
enables us to understand the behavior (malicious or benign) of the accounts. Predictive 
classification of accounts as malicious or benign could help users of the permissionless 
blockchain platforms to operate in a secure manner. Motivated by this, we introduce 
temporal features such as burst and attractiveness on top of several al...
abstract_supported_sentences:
- "Directed Graph based models of a blockchain that capture accounts as nodes and transactions as edges, evolve over time."
- "We introduce temporal features such as burst and attractiveness on top of several already used graph properties"
- "ExtraTreesClassifier performs the best among supervised ML algorithms"
- "Using cosine similarity on top of K-Means clustering identified 554 more suspicious accounts"
- "Using behavior change analysis, we identify 814 unique suspicious accounts across different temporal granularities"

- The abstract does not explicitly mention the limitations of the approach
- The abstract could better clarify that the approach is limited to permissionless blockchains
relevant_body_sentences:
"Our results show that ExtraTreesClassifier performs best under the supervised setting and achieves balanced accuracy in the range [87.2, 88.7] for different dataset configurations." (p.26)
"Under the unsupervised settings, K-Means was able to cluster max 73.9% known malicious accounts together and identify 554 more suspects that had similar behavior to that of malicious accounts." (p.26)
"When considering behavioral changes over time and studying them over different temporal granularities, we are able to detect the probability of an account being malicious at a particular temporal granularity." (p.26)

filename: Ahmadi et al. - 2019 - The communication cost of information spreading in dynamic networks.pdf
filepath: /Users/v/solomonresearch/blockchain sna litrev/PDFs/Ahmadi et al. - 2019 - The communication cost of information spreading in dynamic networks.pdf
abstract_text:
This paper investigates the message complexity of distributed information spreading (a.k.a
gossip or token dissemination) in adversarial dynamic networks. While distributed computations
in dynamic networks have been studied intensively over the last years, almost all of the existing
work solely focuses on the time complexity of distributed algorithms.
In information spreading, the goal is to spread k tokens of information to every node on an
n-node network. We consider the amortized (average) me...
abstract_supported_sentences:
- "This paper investigates the message complexity of distributed information spreading in adversarial dynamic networks"
- "In information spreading, the goal is to spread k tokens of information to every node on an n-node network"
- "We consider two types of adversaries that have been studied extensively in dynamic networks: adaptive and oblivious"
- "We present two sets of results depending on how nodes send messages to their neighbors"
abstract_unsupported_claims:
- The abstract does not explicitly mention the 3-edge stability assumption required for time complexity bounds
- The assumption about knowledge of number of sources and tokens for oblivious case is not mentioned

filename: Al-Quayed et al. - 2025 - Context-Aware Prediction with Secure and Lightweight Cognitive Decision Model in Smart Cities.pdf
filepath: /Users/v/solomonresearch/blockchain sna litrev/PDFs/Al-Quayed et al. - 2025 - Context-Aware Prediction with Secure and Lightweight Cognitive Decision Model in Smart Cities.pdf
abstract_text:
Cognitive networks with the integration of smart and physical devices are rapidly utilized for the development of smart cities. 
They are explored by many real-time applications such as smart homes, healthcare, safety systems, and other unpredictable 
environments to gather data and process network requests. However, due to the external conditions and inherent uncertainty 
of wireless systems, most of the existing approaches cannot cope with routing disturbances and timely delivery performance. ...
findings:
- Proposed model reduces packet drop ratio by 27-38% compared to existing solutions (p.7)
- Energy consumption improved by 27-34% through secured communication and balanced routing (p.8)
- Node overhead reduced by 28.6-35% using iterative forwarding decisions (p.9)
- Response time improved by 23-29% through weighted routing and intelligent computing (p.10)
- Blockchain integration provides data integrity and privacy protection (p.4)
gaps:
- Need for adaptive learning algorithms for cost-effective resource allocation in IoT networks (p.11)
- Lack of real-time processing solutions with low overhead while preserving privacy (p.11)
- Integration of lightweight data encryption methods for constrained devices (p.3)
- Handling mobility issues for high-density networks and dynamic topologies (p.3)
methodologies:
- Reinforcement learning for routing decisions and reward computation (p.4)
- Blockchain technology for security and data integrity (p.3-4)
- Symmetric key cryptography and digital signatures (p.5)
- Simulation testing with varying network parameters (p.6-7)
- Performance evaluation metrics: throughput, packet drop ratio, overhead, energy consumption (p.7)
limitations:
- Does not address mobility issues for high-density networks (p.3)
- Lacks integration of advanced security mechanisms for edge devices (p.3)
- Need for efficient load distribution on heterogeneous devices (p.11)
- Future work needed on mobile SDN controller integration for scalability (p.11)
- Limited evaluation under real-time IoT environments (p.3)
abstract_supported_sentences:
- "Cognitive networks with the integration of smart and physical devices are rapidly utilized for the development of smart cities"
- "This paper presents a secured decision-making model using reinforcement learning with the combination of blockchain to enhance the degree of trust and data protection"
- "The proposed model increases the network efficiency for resource utilization and the management of communication devices"
abstract_unsupported_claims:
- The abstract does not clearly specify the limitations of the proposed approach
- Claims about "timely delivery performance" are not thoroughly validated in results
- The abstract is incomplete and cuts off mid-sentence
relevant_body_sentences:
- "The proposed model uses the concept of reinforcement learning to construct the routing chains for the transmission of network data in sensors-driven applications" (p.4)
- "The combination of blockchain nodes in the routing chains not only achieves data privacy but also provides information integrity using the computation of hashes" (p.11)
- "According to the performance results, the proposed model significantly reduces the node overhead against varying sensors and load by 28.6% and 35%, respectively" (p.9)

"The static analysis needs to consider sequences of n callbacks, e.g., of the form τ1; f1; . . . ; fn;τ2, where the fi (for i = 1, . . . ,n) are function segments for the callbacks to all n different procedures in the program" (p.18)

ceived messages timely to make decision accordingly. In this paper

filename: Alessi et al. - 2019 - A decentralized personal data store based on ethereum Towards GDPR compliance.pdf
filepath: /Users/v/solomonresearch/blockchain sna litrev/PDFs/Alessi et al. - 2019 - A decentralized personal data store based on ethereum Towards GDPR compliance.pdf
findings:
- Developed a decentralized Personal Data Store (PDS) prototype using Ethereum and IPFS (p.1-2)
- Implemented user profile schema based on schema.org ontology with public/private data sections (p.4)
- Created mobile and desktop deployments with QR code-based data sharing (p.5)
- Proposed new architecture with cloud storage and consent mechanism to improve GDPR compliance (p.7-8)
gaps:
- Lack of common approach for handling personal data disclosure and IoT device sharing in decentralized systems (p.1)
- Need for GDPR-compliant decentralized personal data management solutions (p.1-2)
- Challenge of implementing "right to be forgotten" in blockchain systems (p.6)
methodologies:
- Schema.org ontology for user profile modeling (p.3-4)
- Ethereum blockchain for decentralized identity management (p.4)
- IPFS distributed storage system (p.4-5)
- Mobile and desktop prototype implementations (p.5)
- Scenario-based evaluation approach (p.5)
limitations:
- Current prototype lacks full GDPR compliance (p.6)
- Issues with identifying data controllers in public blockchains (p.6)
- Challenge of true data deletion from blockchain (p.6)
- Ethereum's dependence on RSA cryptography vulnerable to quantum computing (p.8-9)
- Need for testing in larger real-world settings (p.8)
- Requires transition from test network to Ethereum mainnet (p.8)
abstract_supported_sentences:
- "Personal data sharing with service providers represents an unavoidable risk..."
- "The current paper offers a contribution, showing that the decentralized approach for personal data sharing, may be compliant not only with the requirement of users' centrality but also with GDPR"
- "This is possible by embedding the consent mechanism described by GDPR, within a real decentralized prototype"
abstract_unsupported_claims: - The abstract overstates the level of GDPR compliance achieved, as the paper acknowledges several remaining compliance challenges
relevant_body_sentences:
"To achieve the goal of a decentralized PDS application, compliant to the GDPR, it is necessary to improve the previous software architecture adding some modules which allow to store personal data in a centralized cloud environment and preserving business logic in a decentralized environment." (p.7)

"The new architecture we have proposed moves further the DIM prototype to better fit the GDPR issues of the right to withdraw and to be forgotten." (p.8)

filename: Atiya and Nawaf - 2020 - Prediction of Link Weight of bitcoin Network by Leveraging the Community Structure.pdf
filepath: /Users/v/solomonresearch/blockchain sna litrev/PDFs/Atiya and Nawaf - 2020 - Prediction of Link Weight of bitcoin Network by Leveraging the Community Structure.pdf
findings:
- The proposed model achieved 4% and 18% minimization for Bitcoin-OTC dataset for all and partial edges respectively (p.2)
- For Bitcoin-Alpha dataset, achieved 0% and 30% minimization for all and partial edges respectively (p.2)
- Community structure approach showed effectiveness in prediction compared to baseline methods (p.9)
- Node attribute representation impacts prediction accuracy (p.9)
- Most Bitcoin communities detected were small in size (p.7-8)
gaps:
- Limited literature addressing weight prediction in Bitcoin networks (p.2)
- Need for identifying untrusted Bitcoin users to avoid risky transactions (p.1)
- Challenge of accurately predicting missing edge weights in Bitcoin networks (p.2)
methodologies:
- Newman-Girvan algorithm for community detection (p.5-6)
- Multiple similarity measures: Pearson correlation, Cosine similarity, Jaccard index (p.6-7)
- Edge weight prediction based on community structure (p.7-8)
- Evaluation using Bitcoin-OTC and Bitcoin-Alpha datasets (p.8)
- 10-90% edge removal in 30% increments for robustness testing (p.8)
limitations:
- Model could not predict all missing edge weights due to lonely nodes in communities (p.8)
- Short data collection period resulted in small community sizes affecting performance (p.9)
- 17-40% of missing links in Bitcoin-OTC and 18-33% in Bitcoin-Alpha could not be predicted (p.8)
- Community structure approach only works when nodes have sufficient neighbors/transactions (p.8)
abstract_supported_sentences:
"The proposed model consists of two main stages; the first one is the detection of trusted Bitcoin communities by implementing Newman-Girvan algorithm."
"Prediction the missing edge weight based on the neighbors of edge-source in community."
"The experimental results explicate the effectiveness of the proposed model comparable with other methods"
abstract_unsupported_claims:
- The abstract does not acknowledge the key limitations of the approach
- Does not mention that the model cannot predict weights for all missing edges
relevant_body_sentences:
"The proposed model has been used a different representation of node attributes and corresponding similarity measures to get the different structure of communities each time." (p.8)
"The best performance is recorded when the high percentage of missing links has not been predicted (part of edges) which indicates the effectiveness of community structure in the prediction process." (p.9)
"Most of the communities are small. Figure (2) shows the distribution of community size." (p.7)

filepath: /Users/v/solomonresearch/blockchain sna litrev/PDFs/Atiya and Nawaf - 2021 - Community structure-aware fairness and goodness algorithm for link weight prediction.pdf
findings:
- Community structure improves prediction accuracy compared to baseline methods (p.9)
- Model performs best with older transactions and numerical feature representation (p.9)
- Error minimization of 18% for Alpha dataset and 26% for OTC dataset (p.8)
- Com-str_tr>1 model with Pearson and Cosine similarity performs best horizontally across experiments (p.8-9)
- Older links are more influential than newly created ones for prediction accuracy (p.9)
gaps:
- Need for improved weight prediction in Bitcoin trust networks (p.2)
- Lack of methods leveraging community structure for weight prediction (p.2)
- Limited understanding of how node attribute representation affects community formation (p.9)
methodologies:
- Newman-Girvan algorithm for community detection (p.4-5)
- Fairness and Goodness measures adapted for community context (p.6-7)
- Multiple similarity measures: Jaccard, Cosine, Pearson correlation (p.6-7)
- Experimental validation on Bitcoin-OTC and Bitcoin-Alpha datasets (p.7)
- 10-90% edge removal in 30% increments to test robustness (p.9)
limitations:
- Small communities do not effectively support the proposed model (p.9)
- Model is sensitive to node attribute representation (p.9)
- Majority of detected communities are too small (2-3 customers) (p.6)
- Cannot discover overlapping communities (p.4)
- Time complexity of O(n^3) for sparse graphs (p.4)
abstract_supported_sentences:
"In this research, the problem of predicting the edge weight in the Bitcoin network has been resolved by utilizing the structure of the community based Fairness and Goodness."
"The model was evaluated in practice using two real-world datasets; the Bitcoin-OTC and the Bitcoin-Alpha datasets."
"The percentage error minimization is 18% for the Alpha dataset and 26% for OTC dataset."
abstract_unsupported_claims: The abstract claims "trusted communities which depends on the features representation generally" but does not fully explain or justify this dependency in the paper body.
relevant_body_sentences:
"The model superior the performance of the baseline and the recent methods as illustrated in table 2" (p.9)
"Specifically, the model so called Com-str_tr>1 scores minimum error" (p.9)
"The experimental findings explain the effectiveness of the proposed comparable with other methods" (p.1)

filename: Aufiero et al. - 2024 - DApps ecosystems mapping the network structure of smart contract interactions.pdf
filepath: /Users/v/solomonresearch/blockchain sna litrev/PDFs/Aufiero et al. - 2024 - DApps ecosystems mapping the network structure of smart contract interactions.pdf
abstract_text:
Decentralized applications (DApps) built on blockchain platforms such as Ethereum
and coded in languages such as Solidity, have recently gained attention for their
potential to disrupt traditional centralized systems. Despite their rapid adoption,
limited research has been conducted to understand the underlying code structure of
these applications. In particular, each DApp is composed of multiple smart contracts,
each containing a number of functions that can be called to trigger a speciﬁc event...
abstract_supported_sentences:
"Despite their rapid adoption, limited research has been conducted to understand the underlying code structure of these applications."
"We show how decentralization is architecturally implemented, identifying common development patterns and anomalies that could influence the system's robustness and efficiency."
"We find a consistent network structure characterized by modular, self-sufficient contracts and a complex web of function interactions"
abstract_unsupported_claims:
The abstract does not explicitly mention the 2% critical threshold for network fragmentation, which is a key finding.
The abstract could better highlight the small-world properties discovered in the networks.
relevant_body_sentences:
"The networks exhibit a low degree, with the majority falling within the range of 2 to 3: the nodes have few connections." (p.14)
"In the majority of cases (20 DApps out of 29), the component becomes disconnected after the removal of just 2% of the nodes" (p.21)
"DApps function networks exhibit a core largest component comprising functions interacting across multiple contracts, and encoding the core DApps' functionalities." (p.24)

filename: Avni et al. - 2025 - A GAME OF PAWNS.pdf
filepath: /Users/v/solomonresearch/blockchain sna litrev/PDFs/Avni et al. - 2025 - A GAME OF PAWNS.pdf
abstract_text:
. We introduce and study pawn games, a class of two-player zero-sum turn-based
graph games. A turn-based graph game proceeds by placing a token on an initial vertex,
and whoever controls the vertex on which the token is located, chooses its next location.
This leads to a path in the graph, which determines the winner. Traditionally, the control
of vertices is predetermined and fixed. The novelty of pawn games is that control of vertices
changes dynamically throughout the game as follows. Each ve...
abstract_supported_sentences:
"We introduce and study pawn games, a class of two-player zero-sum turn-based graph games."
"The novelty of pawn games is that control of vertices changes dynamically throughout the game"
"We study the complexity of solving pawn games, where we focus on reachability objectives and parameterize the problem by the mechanism that is being used"
"On the positive side, even though pawn games are exponentially-succinct turn-based games, we identify several natural classes that can be solved in PTIME"
"On the negative side, we identify several EXPTIME-complete classes"
abstract_unsupported_claims: The abstract does not explicitly mention the PSPACE-completeness result for OMVPP k-grabbing games, which is a significant finding.
relevant_body_sentences:

"MVPP always-grabbing PAWN-GAMES is EXPTIME-complete" (p.21)
"MVPP always-grab-or-give PAWN-GAMES is in PTIME" (p.23)
"OMVPP k-grabbing PAWN-GAMES is PSPACE-complete" (p.28)

filename: Bausch et al. - 2021 - A quantum search decoder for natural language processing.pdf
filepath: /Users/v/solomonresearch/blockchain sna litrev/PDFs/Bausch et al. - 2021 - A quantum search decoder for natural language processing.pdf
abstract_text:
Probabilistic language models, e.g. those based on recurrent neural networks such as long short-term memory models
(LSTMs), often face the problem of finding a high probability prediction from a sequence of random variables over a set
of tokens. This is commonly addressed using a form of greedy decoding such as beam search, where a limited number of
highest-likelihood paths (the beam width) of the decoder are kept, and at the end the maximum-likelihood path is chosen.
In this work, we construct ...
abstract_supported_sentences:
- "Probabilistic language models...often face the problem of finding a high probability prediction from a sequence of random variables over a set of tokens."
- "This is commonly addressed using a form of greedy decoding such as beam search"
- "In this work, we construct a quantum algorithm to find the globally optimal parse with high constant success probability"
abstract_unsupported_claims: - The abstract could better acknowledge the theoretical nature of the results and current practical limitations
relevant_body_sentences:
"While quantum computers are not yet robust enough to evaluate any of these applications on sample sizes large enough to claim an empirical advantage, a structured search problem such as language decoding is a prime candidate for a quantum speedup." (p.2)

"For DeepSpeech, we empirically find that input sequence lengths of up to 500 tokens can realistically be decoded, with an effective beam width of 1015 hypotheses—while requiring ≈3 × 106 search iterations" (p.6)

"As expected, the super-Grover speedup from Corollary 2 is achieved in the regime where full QUANTUMSEARCHDECODING happens" (p.6)

filename: Becchetti et al. - 2020 - Finding a bounded-degree expander inside a dense one.pdf
filepath: /Users/v/solomonresearch/blockchain sna litrev/PDFs/Becchetti et al. - 2020 - Finding a bounded-degree expander inside a dense one.pdf

"It follows from the Marcus-Spielman-Srivastava proof of the Kadison-Singer conjecture that if G = (V, E) is a Δ-regular dense expander then there is an edge-induced subgraph H = (V, EH) of G of constant maximum degree which is also an expander."
"We show that such a subgraph (although with quantitatively weaker expansion and near-regularity properties than those predicted by MSS) can be constructed with high probability in linear time, via a simple algorithm."
"Our algorithm allows a distributed implementation that runs in O(log n) rounds and does O(n) total work with high probability."

"For every d ≥1, every 0 < α ≤1, every c ≥2/α, and for every Δ-regular graph G = (V, E) with Δ= αn, the time complexity of RAES(G, d, c) is O(n) w.h.p." (p.5)
"A sufficiently small constant ε > 0 exists such that, for any constants d ≥44 and 0 < α ≤1, for any sufficiently large c, and every Δ-regular graph G = (V, E) with Δ= αn and second largest eigenvalue of the adjacency matrix λ ≤εα²Δ, RAES(G, d, c) returns a (d, cd)-almost regular ε-expander H = (V, A), w.h.p." (p.6)

filename: Bettinger et al. - 2022 - Collusion-Resistant Worker Set Selection for Transparent and Verifiable Voting.pdf
filepath: /Users/v/solomonresearch/blockchain sna litrev/PDFs/Bettinger et al. - 2022 - Collusion-Resistant Worker Set Selection for Transparent and Verifiable Voting.pdf
findings:
- Random worker selection provides collusion resistance up to 45% of participants as workers with 97.5% confidence (p. 25)
- Graph-aware selection using community detection performs better than random selection, maintaining efficiency until ~50% of voters as workers (p. 25-26)
- For both methods, when using 1/5 of participants as workers (807 out of 4039), collusion resistance is maintained below security threshold (p. 26)
- Analysis of Facebook's social graph structure suggests the approach would scale well to large networks (p. 28-29)
gaps:
- Need for collusion-resistant worker selection in decentralized protocols where trusted entities select workers (p. 2)
- Lack of transparent and verifiable methods for selecting workers in voting protocols (p. 2-3)
- Need for methods to quantify and minimize probability of worker collusion (p. 3)
methodologies:
- Veriifiable random worker selection using blockchain for seed generation (p. 9-14)
- Community detection using Blondel's multilevel algorithm for graph-aware selection (p. 6-7)
- Experimental evaluation using Facebook combined dataset with 4,039 nodes (p. 24)
- Metrics: largest clique size of workers, community properties, inter-worker distances (p. 24)
limitations:
- Time complexity exponential in number of workers for clique size computation (p. 22)
- Random selection requires estimating proportion of malicious participants (p. 29)
- Graph-aware method requires centralized access to social graph (p. 30)
- Privacy concerns with public social graph data (p. 30)
- Need for further analysis of impact of graph structure on collusion resistance (p. 31)
- Need to fully decentralize the graph-based approach (p. 31)
abstract_supported_sentences:
- "We propose two protocols that select a subset of workers from the set of participants such that the probability of the workers colluding together is minimized."
- "Our first solution is a decentralized protocol that randomly selects workers in a verifiable manner without any trusted entities."
- "The second solution is an algorithm that uses a social graph of participants and community detection to select workers that are socially distant"
abstract_unsupported_claims: - The abstract does not explicitly acknowledge the limitations around privacy and centralization of the graph-based approach
relevant_body_sentences:
"Both approaches provided ranges of numbers of workers satisfying the constraints. The decentralized random worker selection works from low numbers of workers to an upper limit which depends on the size of the graph's largest clique." (p. 31)
"As expected, the method taking advantage of the graph's structure provides better results: it distances workers better for a wider range of numbers of workers." (p. 31)

filename: Brigatti et al. - 2023 - Inferring interactions in multispecies communities The cryptocurrency market case.pdf
filepath: /Users/v/solomonresearch/blockchain sna litrev/PDFs/Brigatti et al. - 2023 - Inferring interactions in multispecies communities The cryptocurrency market case.pdf
abstract_text:
We introduce a general framework for empirically detecting interactions in communities of
entities characterized by different features. This approach is inspired by ideas and methods
coming from ecology and finance and is applied to a large dataset extracted from the crypto-
currency market. The inter-species interaction network is constructed using a similarity mea-
sure based on the log-growth rate of the capitalizations of the cryptocurrency market. The
detected relevant interactions are only...
findings:
- Cryptocurrency market shows clear community structure with two practically disjointed communities based on capitalization (p.8)
- Only cooperative interactions detected, no competitive relations found among long-lived cryptocurrencies (p.12)
- Network based on log-growth rates shows more structured topology than price returns-based network (p.13)
- Direct pair interactions correspond to specific features of related currencies (XLM-XRP, BTC-LTC, DASH-XMR) (p.13)
- Network topology suggests less probable widespread contagions due to disjointed nature (p.13)
gaps:
- Need for studies verifying interconnection between cryptoassets and traditional financial system (p.14)
- Limited understanding of competitive relations among extinct-prone coins with short lifetimes (p.12)
- Lack of analysis of third and fourth generation cryptocurrencies' interactions (p.6)
methodologies:
- Maximum Entropy Framework for inferring interactions (p.3)
- Partial correlation analysis to identify direct interactions (p.4-5)
- Minimum/Maximum Spanning Trees for network visualization (p.4-5)
- Log-growth rate analysis of capitalization data (p.3-4)
- Distance metrics based on correlations and partial correlations (p.4-5)
limitations:
- Analysis restricted to pre-2019 data, excluding recent cryptocurrency generations (p.6)
- Focus only on 100 largest capitalization cryptocurrencies (p.5-6)
- Some cryptocurrencies had data gaps that needed to be filled with averages (p.6)
- Limited analysis of time-lagged correlations (p.5)
- Cannot detect competitive interactions among short-lived coins (p.12)
abstract_supported_sentences:
- "The inter-species interaction network is constructed using a similarity measure based on the log-growth rate of the capitalizations"
- "The detected relevant interactions are only of the cooperative type"
- "The network presents a well-defined clustered structure, with two practically disjointed communities"
- "The first one is made up of highly capitalized cryptocurrencies that are tightly connected"
abstract_unsupported_claims:
- The abstract does not explicitly acknowledge the temporal limitations of the study
- No mention of limitations regarding focus on only top 100 cryptocurrencies
relevant_body_sentences:
"The correlation matrix of the growth rate displays a very interesting diagonal block structure generated by the capitalization of cryptocurrencies" (p.12)
"The network generated from the partial correlations of the log-growth rate displays a BTC with important centrality" (p.13)
"This topology suggests less probable widespread contagions, as default cascades should be limited by the disjointed nature of the different network sectors" (p.13)

filename: Chen and Dong - 2020 - Dynamic Network Connectedness of Bitcoin Markets Evidence from Realized Volatility.pdf
filepath: /Users/v/solomonresearch/blockchain sna litrev/PDFs/Chen and Dong - 2020 - Dynamic Network Connectedness of Bitcoin Markets Evidence from Realized Volatility.pdf
findings:
- Spillovers between systematic and idiosyncratic volatilities dominate Bitcoin market connectedness (p.4)
- Idiosyncratic volatility spillovers are more easily influenced by policies (p.6-7)
- Good volatility spillovers dominate Bitcoin markets and change over time (p.7-8)
- Significant asymmetry exists between systematic and idiosyncratic volatility spillovers (p.10-12)
- Asymmetries between good and bad volatility spillovers are heterogeneous across different markets (p.13-14)
- Bad volatility spillovers play leading roles in Bitcoin markets with large capitalization (p.14)
gaps:
- Limited research on volatility connectedness in cryptocurrency markets (p.2)
- Lack of studies on systematic and idiosyncratic decomposition in cryptocurrency markets (p.2)
- Insufficient attention to asymmetries from good and bad volatility in cryptocurrency markets (p.2)
- Need for understanding asymmetric spillover effects across Bitcoin markets (p.3)
methodologies:
- Realized volatility measurement using 5-min frequency data (p.3)
- Generalized dynamic factor models for volatility decomposition (p.3)
- DY spillover index for measuring connectedness (p.3-4)
- Statistical tests for asymmetric spillovers (p.10-11)
- Rolling window analysis for dynamic effects (p.4)
limitations:
- Sample limited to six Bitcoin markets (p.4)
- Fixed rolling window size of 60 periods (p.4)
- Focus only on Bitcoin rather than other cryptocurrencies (p.15)
- Limited time period from March 2016 to March 2020 (p.4)
abstract_supported_sentences:
"The spillovers of systematic and idiosyncratic volatilities dominate the connectedness among different Bitcoin markets."
"The idiosyncratic volatility spillovers are more easily influenced by policies."
"Good volatility spillovers dominate the Bitcoin markets and change over time."
"There is significant asymmetry between systematic and idiosyncratic volatility spillovers in the Bitcoin markets"
abstract_unsupported_claims: None found - all major claims in abstract are supported by evidence in paper body
relevant_body_sentences:

"Good volatility spillovers dominated the Bitcoin markets and changed over time." (p.7)
"There was significant asymmetry between systematic and idiosyncratic volatility spillovers among different Bitcoin markets." (p.15)

filename: Choudhary et al. - 2024 - Assessing Supply Chain Resilience During the Pandemic Using Network Analysis.pdf
filepath: /Users/v/solomonresearch/blockchain sna litrev/PDFs/Choudhary et al. - 2024 - Assessing Supply Chain Resilience During the Pandemic Using Network Analysis.pdf
findings:
- Spatial complexity positively affects supply chain network resilience (p.8-9)
- Average degree negatively influences network resilience (p.9)
- Betweenness centrality of important firms negatively affects resilience while closeness centrality positively affects it (p.9-10)
- Network type remained scale-free throughout disruption period (p.10)
- Average clustering coefficient positively influences resilience (p.10)
gaps:
- Limited research on conceptualizing resilience beyond firm level (p.12)
- Scant research considering networks of heterogeneous agents using real-world data (p.3)
- Few studies considering impact of risk propagation in complex network context (p.3)
- Limited empirical studies on real disruptive events and associated network resilience (p.12)
methodologies:
- Agent-based modeling to simulate network disruptions (p.5-7)
- Network visualization using Gephi 0.9.2 (p.5)
- Multiple regression analysis on simulated results (p.9-10)
- Social network analysis metrics (betweenness centrality, closeness centrality etc.) (p.3-4)
- Snowball sampling for data collection (p.4)
limitations:
- Did not consider heterogeneity of edges/buyer-supplier relationships (p.12)
- Disruption model based on decision-making logic rather than actual network data (p.12)
- No time lag consideration between stringency index increase and node disruption (p.12)
- Assumed firms operate only in headquarter location (p.12)
- Limited data on outsourced projects to firms in other countries (p.12)
abstract_supported_sentences:
"We construct a real supply chain network (scale-free) based on a seed firm (Apple), its customers, and its first- and second-tier suppliers, yielding a network of a total of 883 firms."
"We specifically find that spatial complexity, degree centrality, betweenness centrality, and closeness centrality have changed significantly throughout our observation period."

The abstract generally reflects the paper's content well but could be improved by acknowledging key limitations and constraints of the study methodology.

filename: Dinitz et al. - 2024 - Smoothed Analysis of Information Spreading in Dynamic Networks.pdf
filepath: /Users/v/solomonresearch/blockchain sna litrev/PDFs/Dinitz et al. - 2024 - Smoothed Analysis of Information Spreading in Dynamic Networks.pdf
abstract_text:
The best known solutions for k-message broadcast in dynamic networks of size n require Ω(nk)
rounds. In this paper, we see if these bounds can be improved by smoothed analysis. To do so,
we study perhaps the most natural randomized algorithm for disseminating tokens in this setting:
at every time step, choose a token to broadcast randomly from the set of tokens you know. We
show that with even a small amount of smoothing (...
findings:
- Random broadcast with 1-smoothing solves k-message broadcast in O(n + k^3 log n) rounds, improving on O(nk) bound for k = o(√n) (p. 3)
- With ℓ-smoothing, random broadcast completes in O(kn^(2/3)log^(1/3)(n)/ℓ^(1/3)) rounds (p. 5)
- In static networks with 1-smoothing, random broadcast completes in O(k√n log^2 n) rounds (p. 17-18)
- For well-mixed networks with probability p, random broadcast completes in O((k/p)log n) rounds (p. 21)
gaps:
- Previous work left open whether k-message broadcast bounds could be improved with smoothed analysis (p. 2)
- Gap between strongly adaptive and oblivious adversaries for k-message broadcast was unresolved (p. 5)
- Whether O(nk) bound is fundamental or fragile was unknown (p. 2)
methodologies:
- Predecessor path analysis framework (p. 8-10)
- Smoothed analysis with ℓ random edges added per round (p. 7)
- Three-phase analysis: spread, seed, sink phases (p. 4-5)
- Graph decomposition into components for static networks (p. 17)
limitations:
- Analysis not optimized for constant/log factors (p. 15)
- Gap of (k+ℓ)^(1/3) between upper and lower bounds (p. 15)
- Results only for integer smoothing parameters ℓ, not fractional (p. 11)
- Upper bounds not tight for very large ℓ values (p. 15)
abstract_supported_sentences:
"The best known solutions for k-message broadcast in dynamic networks of size n require Ω(nk) rounds."
"We show that with even a small amount of smoothing (i.e., one random edge added per round), this natural strategy solves k-message broadcast in O(n + k^3) rounds"
abstract_unsupported_claims: The abstract is incomplete as it cuts off mid-sentence. The full scope of results, particularly regarding static networks and well-mixed networks, is not reflected.
relevant_body_sentences:
"We prove that in static networks, 1-smoothing improves the complexity of random broadcast down to O(k√n) rounds, beating what we can guarantee in the dynamic setting." (p. 17)
"Our goal is to prove that even a small amount of smoothing (i.e., ℓ=1) is sufficient to enable random broadcast to outperform the worst-case lower bound." (p. 3)
"We show that random broadcast solves k-message broadcast in O((k/p)log n) rounds, with high probability, when run in a network with a p-mixed token distribution." (p. 21)

filename: Durcheva and Tsankov - 2019 - Analysis of similarities between stock and cryptocurrency series by using graphs and spanning trees.pdf
filepath: /Users/v/solomonresearch/blockchain sna litrev/PDFs/Durcheva and Tsankov - 2019 - Analysis of similarities between stock and cryptocurrency series by using graphs and spanning trees.pdf
findings:
- Cryptocurrency networks tend to be more correlated compared to NASDAQ stocks with smaller node dissimilarities (p.11)
- Node degree distributions follow power law patterns for both crypto and stock networks (p.11)
- High cap assets like BTC, ETH, MSFT, GOOGL tend to be central nodes (p.7-8)
- NASDAQ shows more distinct clustering by sector compared to crypto networks (p.7-8)
- ETH is consistently the most central node in crypto networks, likely due to its ecosystem role (p.6)
- MSFT and major tech stocks form persistent clusters in NASDAQ networks (p.7)
gaps:
- Need for analysis across different time periods and market conditions (p.11)
- Limited understanding of volatility series patterns and node degree stability (p.11)
- Lack of comparison with other major stock markets like European and S&P stocks (p.11)
- Need to investigate cases where FFT and correlation measures produce different results (p.7-8)
methodologies:
- Correlation-based similarity measures (p.3-4)
- Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) based similarity analysis (p.4-5)
- Minimum spanning trees using Kruskal's algorithm (p.5)
- Graph filtering algorithm for dense network analysis (p.6-7)
- Node degree and edge weight distribution analysis (p.7-11)
limitations:
- Dataset limited to 100 assets each for crypto and NASDAQ (p.3)
- Fixed time window of 500 days (p.3-4)
- Potential noise sensitivity in FFT measures (p.7)
- Need for more accurate volatility modeling (p.11)
- Results not validated across different market conditions (p.11)
- Statistical significance limited by dataset size (p.11)

filename: Elsayed and Sousa - 2024 - International monetary policy and cryptocurrency markets dynamic and spillover effects.pdf
filepath: /Users/v/solomonresearch/blockchain sna litrev/PDFs/Elsayed and Sousa - 2024 - International monetary policy and cryptocurrency markets dynamic and spillover effects.pdf
abstract_text:
Using daily data over the period August 5, 2013 – September 27, 2019, this study
investigates the dynamic spillovers between international monetary policies across
four major economies (i.e. Eurozone, Japan, UK and US) and three key cryptocurren-
cies (i.e. Bitcoin, Litecoin and Ripple). In doing so, we apply a Time-Varying Parameter
VectorAuto-Regression(TVP-VAR)model,adynamicconnectednessapproachandnet-
work analysis. The empirical results indicate that cryptocurrency returns and monetary
poli...
findings:
- Total connectedness index of 24.86% between monetary policy and cryptocurrencies (p. 8-9)
- Cryptocurrency returns and monetary policy spillovers were large when shadow rates were negative, moderated during Fed tapering, and increased recently (p. 9-10)
- US is generally net transmitter of shocks while Japan is net receiver (p. 13)
- Strong interconnectedness between US/Eurozone/UK monetary policy and between Bitcoin/Litecoin (p. 13-14)
- Slightly larger spillovers during unconventional vs conventional monetary policy periods (p. 14-15)
gaps:
- Limited research on cryptocurrency response to monetary policy (p. 3)
- Lack of consensus on how cryptocurrencies respond to monetary policy events (p. 3)
- Most existing studies assume static/time-invariant relationship between monetary policy and cryptocurrencies (p. 6)
- Need to examine spillovers between cryptocurrencies and micro/macro-prudential policies (p. 16)
methodologies:
- Time-Varying Parameter Vector Auto-Regression (TVP-VAR) model (p. 5)
- Dynamic connectedness approach of Diebold and Yilmaz (2009, 2012, 2014) (p. 5-6)
- Network analysis using ForceAtlas2 algorithm (p. 7)
- Generalised forecast-error variance decompositions (GFEVD) (p. 6)
- Daily data analysis over 2013-2019 period (p. 7)
limitations:
- Sample period constrained by data availability (p. 7)
- Focus only on major cryptocurrencies and economies (p. 7)
- Potential sensitivity to choice of forecast horizons (p. 17, footnote 3)
- Need for future research on frequency-domain spillover methods (p. 16)
- Limited analysis of regulatory arbitrage aspects (p. 16)
abstract_supported_sentences:
- "Using daily data over the period August 5, 2013 – September 27, 2019..."
- "The empirical results indicate that cryptocurrency returns and monetary policy spillovers were particularly large when shadow policy rates became negative..."
- "Gross directional spillovers suggest that shadow policy rates have more 'to give than to receive'"
abstract_unsupported_claims:
- The abstract does not explicitly mention some limitations of the study
- Does not fully clarify the relative strength of spillover effects
relevant_body_sentences:
"Our framework reveals not only a relatively large degree of interconnectedness, but also one that is time-varying in nature." (p. 16)
"The total connectedness index (TCI) is 24.86%, that is, close to one fourth of the forecast error-variance in all variables comes, on average, from spillovers" (p. 8-9)
"Our network analysis also reveals strong interconnected between monetary policy in either the US or the Eurozone and the UK, and between Bitcoin and Litecoin." (p. 16)

The abstract generally provides an accurate representation of the paper's content and findings, though it could have better acknowledged some limitations. The methodologies mentioned are thoroughly implemented and the main conclusions are well-supported by the analysis.

filename: Erdin et al. - 2020 - A Bitcoin payment network with reduced transaction fees and confirmation times.pdf
filepath: /Users/v/solomonresearch/blockchain sna litrev/PDFs/Erdin et al. - 2020 - A Bitcoin payment network with reduced transaction fees and confirmation times.pdf
findings:
- Heuristic approach achieves comparable results to optimal MIOP solution while allowing better scalability (p.9)
- Torus and BA model topologies perform similarly to fully connected networks but with much better computational efficiency (p.11)
- Privacy-preserving routing increases computation time 3-4x but maintains similar edge counts and investment costs (p.14)
- BA model topology provides better solutions than Torus in terms of edges and capacity, while Torus has computational time advantage (p.15)
gaps:
- Current Lightning Network relies on relay nodes which can become monopolies and security vulnerabilities (p.5)
- Random network formation without topology planning leads to connectivity and capacity issues (p.5)
- Need for planned approach to create private payment networks with guaranteed connectivity and fair cost distribution (p.5)
methodologies:
- Mixed Integer Optimization Programming (MIOP) model for optimal network design (p.6-7)
- Linear Programming (LP) model for flow optimization (p.7)
- Pruning-based heuristic algorithm for scalable network formation (p.7-8)
- Comparison across different initial topologies: fully connected, torus, BA model, hypercube, star (p.9-14)
limitations:
- MIOP model does not scale well due to NP-hardness (p.7)
- Heuristic approach requires careful selection of IUBpN parameter (p.10)
- Privacy guarantees increase computational overhead significantly (p.14)
- Trade-off between computational efficiency and optimal network properties (p.15)

filename: Gong et al. - 2023 - GRATDet Smart Contract Vulnerability Detector Based on Graph Representation and Transformer.pdf
filepath: /Users/v/solomonresearch/blockchain sna litrev/PDFs/Gong et al. - 2023 - GRATDet Smart Contract Vulnerability Detector Based on Graph Representation and Transformer.pdf
findings:
- GRATDet achieves 95.16% F1 score on reentrancy vulnerability detection, exceeding state-of-the-art methods (p. 1450)
- Graph structure module improves F1 scores by 3.14% and 4.33% on two datasets compared to baseline (p. 1454-1455)
- Data augmentation significantly improves detection performance across all metrics (p. 1459)
- Model demonstrates robustness against common code errors and maintains consistent predictions (p. 1458-1459)
gaps:
- Current vulnerability detection methods rely on fixed expert rules which are inefficient (p. 1439)
- Existing deep learning approaches don't fully leverage contract semantic information (p. 1439)
- Limited research on combining global and local structural information for vulnerability detection (p. 1444)
- Lack of publicly available data for other types of smart contract vulnerabilities (p. 1460)
methodologies:
- Line Graph (LG) representation incorporating control and data relationships (p. 1447-1448)
- Data augmentation through swapping, insertion and symbolization (p. 1445-1446)
- Improved Transformer-GP model with graph structure and tensor-product modules (p. 1448-1450)
- Experimental evaluation on two test sets with comparison to baseline methods (p. 1451-1459)
limitations:
- Only evaluated on reentrancy vulnerabilities due to data limitations (p. 1460)
- Tensor-Product module doesn't improve performance for all model variants (p. 1456-1457)
- Adding more graph information layers doesn't always lead to better outcomes (p. 1456)
- Need for future work on data collection for other vulnerability types (p. 1460)
abstract_supported_sentences:
- "Smart contracts have led to more efficient development in finance and healthcare, but vulnerabilities in contracts pose high risks to their future applications."
- "The method first performs swapping, insertion, and symbolization operations for contract functions, increasing the amount of small sample data."
- "The effectiveness of the method in reentrancy vulnerability detection is verified in experiments, where the F1 score reaches 95.16%, exceeding state-of-the-art methods."
abstract_unsupported_claims:
- The abstract doesn't acknowledge the limitation of only testing on reentrancy vulnerabilities
- No explicit mention of healthcare applications in the main paper
relevant_body_sentences:
"The F1 score reaches 95.16%, exceeding state-of-the-art methods" is supported by:
"The Transformer–GP model achieves the best results with F1 scores of 95.16% and 87.67% on the two test sets" (p. 1456)

"The method first performs swapping, insertion, and symbolization operations" is supported by:
"This paper borrows the EDA method in natural language processing and combines the three steps of swap, insertion, and symbolization to augment the data" (p. 1445)

filename: Goodell and Goutte - 2021 - Diversifying equity with cryptocurrencies during COVID-19.pdf
filepath: /Users/v/solomonresearch/blockchain sna litrev/PDFs/Goodell and Goutte - 2021 - Diversifying equity with cryptocurrencies during COVID-19.pdf
findings:
- Co-movements between cryptocurrencies and equity indices gradually increased during COVID-19 (p.2-3)
- Most cryptocurrencies show modest positive correlation with equities, suggesting limited diversification benefit (p.2-3)
- Tether exhibits significant negative correlation with equities, especially during COVID-19 waves (p.3-4)
- Tether acts as an important safe haven during market turmoil due to its USD-pegged stability (p.7-8)
- Bitcoin, Ethereum and Litecoin show increased positive correlation with each other during pandemic period (p.4)
- Contagion between tether and equity indices spiked during successive COVID-19 waves (p.6-7)
gaps:
- Whether cryptocurrencies provide diversification for equities during extreme market conditions (p.1)
- How COVID-19 impacts relationships between different types of cryptocurrencies and equity markets (p.1-2)
- Role of stablecoins like tether as safe havens during severe economic downturns (p.2)
- Impact of COVID-19 on previously identified financial market dynamics and correlations (p.1)
methodologies:
- Wavelet coherence analysis (p.5)
- Neural network analysis (p.3-4)
- Correlation analysis using heatmaps (p.3)
- Time series analysis covering pre-COVID and COVID periods (p.2)
limitations:
- Study period limited to one year pre-COVID and one year during COVID (p.2)
- Focus only on select cryptocurrencies and equity indices (p.2)
- Analysis primarily focused on correlation/co-movement rather than causation (p.10)
- Results may be specific to COVID-19 crisis rather than generalizable to all market downturns (p.10)
abstract_supported_sentences:
- "Literature suggests assets become more correlated during economic downturns"
- "We find co-movements between cryptocurrencies and equity indices gradually increased as COVID-19 progressed"
- "Tether co-moves negatively with equities to an economically significant degree, both pre COVID-19, and considerably more during COVID-19"
abstract_unsupported_claims: - The claim about extending "deeper into the pandemic period than most previous studies" is not thoroughly substantiated in the paper

filename: Guo et al. - 2024 - A Time-Varying Network for Cryptocurrencies.pdf
filepath: /Users/v/solomonresearch/blockchain sna litrev/PDFs/Guo et al. - 2024 - A Time-Varying Network for Cryptocurrencies.pdf
abstract_text:
Cryptocurrencies return cross-predictability and technological similarity yield information
on risk propagation and market segmentation. To investigate these eﬀects, we build a time-
varying network for cryptocurrencies, based on the evolution of return cross-predictability and
technological similarities. We develop a dynamic covariate-assisted spectral clustering method
to consistently estimate the latent community structure of cryptocurrencies network that
accounts for both sets of information...
findings:
- Dynamic CASC algorithm achieves superior classification accuracy over benchmark methods in simulations (p.21-24)
- Investors can achieve better risk diversification by investing in cross-community cryptos, with significantly higher within-community vs cross-community correlations (p.27-29)
- Inter-crypto momentum trading strategy generates 1.08% daily return (p.30)
- Portfolio returns are not driven by behavioral factors like limit-to-arbitrage, investor attention, or policy uncertainty (p.31-34)
gaps:
- Lack of fundamental metrics for comparing cryptocurrencies unlike traditional assets (p.2)
- Need for methods to analyze sparse networks and identify additional linkages between cryptos (p.8)
- Limited understanding of how technological similarities affect crypto prices (p.8)
- Gap in theoretical frameworks for analyzing dynamic networks with time-varying memberships (p.37)
methodologies:
- Dynamic covariate-assisted spectral clustering (CASC) algorithm (p.11-18)
- Adaptive Lasso regression for return cross-predictability (p.6)
- Network analysis combining return cross-predictability and technological similarities (p.8-10)
- Portfolio analysis and behavioral factor testing (p.27-34)
limitations:
- Analysis limited to top 400 cryptos by market cap, further reduced to 182 due to data availability (p.6)
- Theoretical bounds on classification accuracy not tight enough to fully inform information gains (p.21)
- Need for further research on statistical inference for dynamic networks (p.37)
- Limited to specific technological attributes (algorithms and proof types) (p.8-9)
abstract_supported_sentences:
"Cryptocurrencies return cross-predictability and technological similarity yield information on risk propagation and market segmentation."
"We demonstrate that investors can achieve better risk diversification by investing in cryptocurrencies from different communities."
"A cross-sectional portfolio that implements an inter-crypto momentum trading strategy earns a [1.08% daily return]"
abstract_unsupported_claims:
- The abstract does not explicitly mention limitations of the study
- The abstract could better clarify the scope of the analysis being limited to a subset of cryptocurrencies
relevant_body_sentences:

"The return correlations between cryptos within the same community are, on average, significantly higher than those across communities" (p.28)
"The long-short portfolio generates a one-day-ahead average daily return of 1.08% (t-stat. 12.24), statistically significant at the 1% level" (p.30)

filename: Hakim et al. - 2024 - A Decade in Blockchain A Bibliometric Reflection on the Growth and Interdisciplinary Reach of a Dis.pdf
filepath: /Users/v/solomonresearch/blockchain sna litrev/PDFs/Hakim et al. - 2024 - A Decade in Blockchain A Bibliometric Reflection on the Growth and Interdisciplinary Reach of a Dis.pdf
findings:
- China dominates blockchain research with 5,215 publications and 102,881 citations (p. 643)
- Total of 13,369 publications by 52,009 authors from 2013-2023 (p. 635)
- IEEE Access is the leading publication venue with 832 papers and 30,365 citations (p. 646)
- Key research themes include smart contracts, security, IoT integration, and sustainability (p. 652-653)
- Average citation per paper is 19.93 with total citations of 266,483 (p. 635)
gaps:
- Limited participation from developing nations in blockchain research (p. 656)
- Need for integration of grey literature and industry reports (p. 659)
- Lack of real-time monitoring of emerging trends (p. 659)
- Need for more qualitative assessment of influential papers (p. 659)
methodologies:
- Bibliometric analysis using Scopus database (p. 632-633)

filename: Hasan et al. - 2023 - Smart Contract-Based Access Control Framework for Internet of Things Devices.pdf
filepath: /Users/v/solomonresearch/blockchain sna litrev/PDFs/Hasan et al. - 2023 - Smart Contract-Based Access Control Framework for Internet of Things Devices.pdf
abstract_text:
The Internet of Things (IoT) has recently attracted much interest from researchers due to
its diverse IoT applications. However, IoT systems encounter additional security and privacy threats.
Developing an efﬁcient IoT system is challenging because of its sophisticated network topology.
Effective access control is required to ensure user privacy in the Internet of Things. Traditional
access control methods are inappropriate for IoT systems because most conventional access control
approaches are ...
findings:
- Smart contract-based access control framework successfully implemented with three phases: initialization, access control protocol, and inspection (p. 5-12)
- Framework achieves lower gas consumption (46,935 gas) compared to existing solutions (60,785-130,000 gas) (p. 18)
- Security analysis using Slither showed only two low-level issues with no impact on efficiency or security (p. 17)
- Framework successfully addresses usability, security, scalability, interoperability and automation requirements compared to existing solutions (p. 19)
gaps:
- Current IoT systems cannot guarantee trust and privacy for data (p. 2)
- Traditional access control methods are inappropriate for IoT due to centralized design (p. 1)
- Existing solutions fail to address emerging IoT challenges around usability, scalability, interoperability, security and automation (p. 2)
- Need for distributed security measures to ensure IoT system protection (p. 2)
methodologies:
- Smart contract development using Remix IDE and Solidity (p. 15)
- Deployment and testing on Ropsten Ethereum testnet (p. 15)
- Security analysis using Slither tool (p. 17)
- Case study implementation using NodeMCU board and LED control system (p. 13-15)
- Cost comparison analysis with existing solutions (p. 17-19)
limitations:
- Implementation limited to just two devices as proof-of-concept (p. 12)
- No graphical user interface developed (p. 12)
- Need for deeper integration with emerging blockchain technologies like sharding (p. 20)
- Requirement for AI/ML integration to enhance security measures (p. 20)
- High overall deployment costs compared to default gas limits (p. 18)
abstract_supported_sentences:
- "Traditional access control methods are inappropriate for IoT systems because most conventional access control approaches are designed for centralized systems."
- "This paper proposes a decentralized access control framework based on smart contracts with three parts: initialization, an access control protocol, and an inspection."
- "The framework also penalizes users for attempting unauthorized access to the IoT resources."
abstract_unsupported_claims:

filename: Hosseini and Ivanov - 2020 - Bayesian networks for supply chain risk, resilience and ripple effect analysis A literature review.pdf
filepath: /Users/v/solomonresearch/blockchain sna litrev/PDFs/Hosseini and Ivanov - 2020 - Bayesian networks for supply chain risk, resilience and ripple effect analysis A literature review.pdf
abstract_text:
In the broad sense, the Bayesian networks (BN) are probabilistic graphical models that possess unique 
methodical features to model dependencies in complex networks, such as forward and backward 
propagation (inference) of disruptions. BNs have transitioned from an emerging topic to a growing 
research area in supply chain (SC) resilience and risk analysis. As a result, there is an acute need to 
review existing literature to ascertain recent developments and uncover future areas of research. De...
findings:
- BNs are powerful tools for capturing interdependencies among risks and their impacts on SC performance (p.17)
- BNs enable both forward propagation (cause to effect) and backward propagation (effect to cause) analysis of disruptions (p.25-26)
- BNs can work effectively with small/incomplete datasets and combine different knowledge sources (p.25-26)
- BNs are particularly suitable for modeling complex SC systems with high levels of interaction between humans, cyber-physical systems and digital technology (p.26)
- Machine learning can be integrated with BNs to analyze big data SC problems (p.28-29)
gaps:
- Lack of extensive review of BN applications to SC risk and resilience (p.3)
- Limited research on dynamic BN models for SC resilience (p.34)
- Need for more research on analyzing SC structural complexity using BNs (p.34)
- Gap in hybrid BN approaches combining with other risk analysis methods (p.34)
- Limited work on temporal dynamics in BN models (p.29)
methodologies:
- Network analysis (p.3)
- Visualization-based scientometric analysis (p.3)
- Clustering analysis (p.3)
- Term mapping visualization (p.6-7)
- Journal co-citation analysis (p.8)
- Bayesian network modeling (throughout)
limitations:
- Cannot model systems with cyclic flows like closed loop SCs (p.29)
- Poor representation of temporal dynamics (p.29)
- Results depend heavily on reliability of prior knowledge (p.29)
- Computational time increases significantly with large time-slices (p.29)
- Limited ability to model feedback loops due to acyclic nature (p.29)
abstract_supported_sentences:
- "BNs are probabilistic graphical models that possess unique methodical features to model dependencies in complex networks"
- "BNs have transitioned from an emerging topic to a growing research area in supply chain resilience and risk analysis"
- "Despite the increasing number of publications on BNs in the domain of SC uncertainty, an extensive review on their application to SC risk and resilience is lacking"
abstract_unsupported_claims: - The abstract does not clearly state the limitations of BNs that are discussed in the paper
relevant_body_sentences:
"BNs are powerful tools for capturing interdependencies among risks and their impacts on SC performance" (p.17)
"BNs provide a conceptual line of reasoning from cause to effect (forward inference) and effect to cause (inverse inference)" (p.25)
"A key feature of BNs is that they use prior information and can easily synthesize historical data and expert knowledge" (p.26)

The abstract generally reflects the paper's content well but could have better acknowledged the limitations of BN approaches that are discussed in detail in the paper. The methodological claims and findings are well-supported throughout the text.

filename: Hsiao and Sung - 2021 - Employing Blockchain Technology to Strengthen Security of Wireless Sensor Networks.pdf

abstract_text:
The proposed approach uses blockchain-based technology to strengthen the data security of
wireless sensor networks (WSNs). This paper integrates blockchain-based technology with data transfer to
establish an extremely secure WSNs structure. The present wireless network is built on the architecture
of the Internet of Things (IoT) and employs a blockchain-based method to make the reliability of data
transmission strong. In this proposed research, many small-area wireless sensor networks establish ...
findings:
- Integration of blockchain technology strengthens WSN security through decentralized data storage and tamper-proof records (p.72327-72328)
- System achieves nearly comparable performance to traditional methods while providing enhanced security (p.72338)
- Data tampering probability is significantly reduced with blockchain implementation compared to traditional WSNs (p.72338-72339)

gaps:

methodologies:

- SHA256 hash function and cryptographic algorithms (p.72334-72335)
- Vector Kalman filtering for local data fusion (p.72332-72333)
- Neural network-based global fusion algorithm (p.72333)
- JavaScript and Node.js implementation (p.72337-72338)
limitations:
- Data transmission delays due to blockchain processing (p.72340)
- Increased computation time with large amounts of measurement data (p.72340)
- Need for simplified hash function calculations (p.72340)
- System efficiency decreases with increased data volume (p.72340)

findings:

- Performance evaluation using packet delivery ratio and packet drop percentage metrics (p.18-20)
limitations:
- Algorithm complexity of N2 may impact performance in large networks (p.11)
- Performance approaches unmodified OLSR in extreme attack scenarios with >70% malicious nodes (p.19-20)

filename: Irshad et al. - 2024 - GCF-MLD Integrated Approach for Money Laundering Detection Using Machine Learning and Graph Network.pdf
filepath: /Users/v/solomonresearch/blockchain sna litrev/PDFs/Irshad et al. - 2024 - GCF-MLD Integrated Approach for Money Laundering Detection Using Machine Learning and Graph Network.pdf
abstract_text:
Money laundering is a critical issue for financial institutions especially in developing countries
and detecting such suspicious activities is a challenging task. The rule-based money laundering detection
systems currently being used by the financial institutions rely on pre-defined rules that are often not able
to keep up with rapidly changing tactics of money launderers. In this regard, machine learning based
approaches have gained attention for detecting suspicious transactions related to mon...
findings:
- Hierarchical clustering achieved better results with precision of 87.32%, recall of 82.67%, and F1 score of 0.8493 (p.9-10)
- K-means clustering showed precision of 84.12%, recall of 70.67%, and F1 score of 0.7681 (p.9)
- Both clustering algorithms demonstrated low false positive rates (<0.001) and high true negative rates (>0.998) (p.10)
- The model successfully identified suspicious accounts by combining graph network analysis with clustering techniques (p.10)
gaps:
- Current rule-based systems rely on predefined rules that cannot keep up with evolving money laundering tactics (p.1)
- Existing solutions lack consideration of all relevant features helpful in detecting money laundering (p.2)
- Previous models have not been rigorously tested on large volumes of real banking transactions (p.2)
methodologies:
- Graph Network Analysis using NetworkX library to analyze account relationships (p.7-8)
- Calculation of centrality measures including Betweenness Centrality, Degree Centrality & PageRank (p.7)
- K-means and Hierarchical Clustering algorithms (p.7-8)
- Principal Component Analysis (PCA) for visualization (p.8)
- Integration of graph-based features with transaction and account-level features (p.8)
limitations:
- Dataset contains limited number of suspicious accounts which could cause bias (p.5)
- Subjective judgment in labeling suspicious accounts may affect accuracy (p.5)
- Model requires significant computational resources for large-scale networks (p.10)
- Batch processing may be needed to handle very large datasets (p.10)

reach, but also effectively control the cost of advertising while maintaining the scope of diffusio...
findings:

- Two-stage IMON algorithm combining heuristic and greedy approaches (p.162001-162002)

filename: J. Ye et al. - 2018 - Mining Resource Community and Resource Role Network From Event Logs.pdf

abstract_text:
This paper deals with the perspective of organization based on process mining, which
concentrates on activities and performers (resources) in event logs. A classic social network only reﬂects

resource community net with optimal modularity. Moreover, we ﬁnd that there are some resources pl...
findings:
- Developed Resource Community Discovery (RCD) algorithm that constructs resource communities with optimal modularity (p.2-3)
- Created algorithm to transform social networks into weighted community networks (p.6-7)
- Developed method to identify multi-role resources across different communities (p.7-8)
- Achieved higher modularity compared to existing algorithms in experimental validation (p.8-9)
- Successfully identified 25 multi-role resources in airline company case study (p.8-9)
gaps:
- Classic social networks only show relationships between individuals but not role-based communities (p.1)
- Existing methods cannot effectively discover multi-role resources (p.2)
- Current approaches are time-consuming due to need to find all maximal cliques (p.2)
methodologies:
- Resource Community Discovery (RCD) algorithm using modularity gain metric (p.2-3)
- Weighted Community Network transformation algorithm (p.6-7)
- Resource Role Network Discovery algorithm using node fitness function (p.7-8)
- Experimental validation using real-world event logs (p.8-9)
- Case study applications in banking and airline industries (p.7-9)
limitations:
- Local optimum issues in transformation process from weighted community to resource role network (p.8-9)
- Deviations due to random initial community selection (p.9)
- Need for dynamic correction parameters in equations (p.9)

- Resource failures not considered in current work (p.9)

filename: Jeltsch and Díaz - 2022 - Correctness of Broadcast via Multicast Graphically and Formally.pdf
filepath: /Users/v/solomonresearch/blockchain sna litrev/PDFs/Jeltsch and Díaz - 2022 - Correctness of Broadcast via Multicast Graphically and Formally.pdf
findings:
- Proved behavioral equivalence between broadcast via multicast and direct broadcast for a specific pair of networks using weak bisimilarity up to loss (p.43)
- Developed a domain-specific language for describing communication networks that corresponds to hierarchical Petri nets (p.39-40)
- Created graphical notation (communication nets) for visualizing and reasoning about network processes (p.39-40)
- Formalized and machine-checked the proof using Isabelle/HOL (p.47)
gaps:
- Lack of prior work studying equivalence between direct broadcast and broadcast via multicast approaches (p.48)
- Need for generalization to arbitrary strongly connected multicast networks (p.49)
- Need for proofs with state-dependent filters and non-lossy receive channels (p.49)
methodologies:
- Process calculus embedding of domain-specific language (p.37-38)
- Graphical reasoning using communication nets notation (p.39-41)
- Weak bisimilarity up to loss for behavioral equivalence (p.42-43)
- Machine-checked formal proofs in Isabelle/HOL (p.47)
- Equational reasoning style proof approach (p.47)
limitations:
- Proof only covers a specific pair of networks rather than arbitrary topologies (p.43)
- Not all fundamental lemmas used in the proof have been proved yet (p.43)
- Time constraints prevented proving all lemmas (p.43)
- Current work is limited to fixed predicate packet filtering (p.49)
abstract_supported_sentences:
"Maintaining data consistency among multiple parties requires nodes to repeatedly send data to all other nodes."
"The scientific literature typically takes the ideal perspective that such data distribution is performed by broadcasting to all nodes directly, while in practice data is distributed by repeated multicast."
"For describing systems that distribute data, we use a domain-specific language of processes that corresponds to a class of Petri nets and is embedded in a general-purpose process calculus."
abstract_unsupported_claims: The abstract implies the proof is more general than it actually is - it only covers a specific pair of networks rather than arbitrary topologies.
relevant_body_sentences:
"In this work, however, we prove this equivalence only for the particular networks depicted in Fig. 3, which nevertheless capture important phenomena that show up in other cases" (p.43)
"We have developed our proof formally using Isabelle/HOL. The proof is phrased in a style similar to equational reasoning" (p.47)
"Our tandem of the communication language and its communication net notation, described in Sect. 2, fits right into all this research: the communication language can be regarded as a restricted process calculus that comes with a Petri net semantics" (p.48)

filename: K. -H. Ho et al. - 2024 - Exploring Key Properties and Predicting Price Movements of Cryptocurrency Market Using Social Networ.pdf
filepath: /Users/v/solomonresearch/blockchain sna litrev/PDFs/K. -H. Ho et al. - 2024 - Exploring Key Properties and Predicting Price Movements of Cryptocurrency Market Using Social Networ.pdf
abstract_text:
The emerging cryptocurrency market is one of the largest financial markets in the world,
with a market capitalization that is already surpassing the gross domestic product of many developed
economies. Cryptocurrencies are increasingly being adopted as a means of transaction and ownership in the
digital domain, particularly in areas like decentralized finance and non-fungible tokens. Known for its high
volatility, this market offers investors the potential for higher returns than traditional fina...
findings:
- Cryptocurrencies are positively and moderately correlated with each other in recent years (p.65064)
- Cryptocurrencies become more tightly correlated during critical events/corrections (p.65064-65065)
- Recent cryptocurrency market shows lighter-tailed correlation distribution compared to past (p.65065)
- Network structure changes during corrections - becomes more compact during corrections and sparser after (p.65067)
- Return correlations are stable short-term but less stable long-term (p.65068-65069)
- Impact of market corrections tends to be short-lived (p.65072)
- Scale-free behavior exhibited by cryptocurrency networks most of the time (p.65069-65070)
- Centrality measures improve accuracy of price movement predictions by 3-5% (p.65074-65075)
gaps:
- Key properties of cryptocurrency market not fully explored previously (p.65060)
- Limited research on using centrality measures as predictors for cryptocurrency prices (p.65060)
- Need for comprehensive dynamic analysis of cryptocurrency market properties over time (p.65060)
methodologies:
- Social network analysis using minimum spanning trees (p.65061)
- Cross-return correlation coefficient analysis (p.65061)
- Centrality measures (degree, node strength, betweenness, closeness, eigenvector) (p.65062-65063)
- LSTM deep learning for price movement prediction (p.65073)
- Rolling window analysis for dynamic evaluation (p.65063)
limitations:
- Exclusion of emerging and yet-to-mature cryptocurrencies (p.65075)
- Reliance only on MST method for network construction (p.65075)
- Limited predictors used for price movement prediction (p.65075)
- Need to incorporate more factors like blockchain data and market sentiment (p.65075)
abstract_supported_sentences:

"Known for its high volatility, this market offers investors the potential for higher returns than traditional financial markets"
"We propose the use of social network analysis to effectively model and analyze the cryptocurrency market"
"We propose the use of centrality measures as novel indicators to improve the accuracy"

"Centrality measures serve as valuable indicators to enhance the precision of predicting short-term fluctuations in cryptocurrency prices" (p.65074)
