filename: Kajol et al. - 2025 - Drivers influencing the adoption of cryptocurrency a social network analysis approach.pdf
filepath: /Users/v/solomonresearch/blockchain sna litrev/PDFs/Kajol et al. - 2025 - Drivers influencing the adoption of cryptocurrency a social network analysis approach.pdf
abstract_text:
Cryptocurrency has gained popularity as a potential new global payment method. 
It has the potential to be faster, cheaper, and more secure than existing payment 
networks, making it a game-changer in the global economy. However, more research 
is needed to identify the factors driving cryptocurrency adoption and understand 
its impact. We use social network analysis (SNA) to identify the influencing factors 
and reveal the impact of each on cryptocurrency adoption. Our analysis initially 
revea...
findings:
- Discomfort and optimism are the most influential factors affecting cryptocurrency adoption (p.17-18)
- Trust, risk, relative advantage, social influence, and perceived behavioral control are moderately influential factors (p.17)
- Price/value, facilitating conditions, compatibility and usefulness are least influential factors (p.16-17)
- The factors affecting cryptocurrency adoption are interdependent as shown through network analysis (p.16)
- Cryptocurrency adoption requires addressing both technical and psychological barriers (p.18-19)
gaps:
- Limited research on relative importance/ranking of factors influencing cryptocurrency adoption (p.3)
- Few studies have classified adoption factors based on their influence levels (p.3)
- Lack of comprehensive frameworks examining interdependencies between adoption factors (p.2)
- Need for more research on policy and regulatory frameworks for cryptocurrency (p.19)
methodologies:
- Social Network Analysis (SNA) using UCINET software (p.10)
- Three-round Delphi technique with 13 experts (p.10-12)
- Systematic literature review using PRISMA model (p.6)
- Degree centrality and betweenness centrality measures (p.12-13)
- Network visualization and interpretation (p.13-14)
limitations:
- Expert panel recruited only from India, limiting geographical scope (p.19)
- Focus only on degree and betweenness centrality measures (p.19)
- Dynamic nature of cryptocurrency adoption not captured in static analysis (p.19)
- Sample size of 13 experts could be expanded (p.10)
- Does not examine differences between developed and developing countries (p.19)
abstract_supported_sentences:
- "We use social network analysis (SNA) to identify the influencing factors and reveal the impact of each on cryptocurrency adoption"
- "Our analysis initially revealed 44 influential factors, which were later reduced to 25 factors"
- "Discomfort and optimism are the most influential determinants of adoption"
- "Moderately influential factors include trust, risk, relative advantage, social influence, and perceived behavioral control"
abstract_unsupported_claims:
- "It has the potential to be faster, cheaper, and more secure than existing payment networks" - This claim is not thoroughly substantiated in the paper
- "making it a game-changer in the global economy" - This is an overstatement not fully supported by the research
relevant_body_sentences:
"Based on the SNA, discomfort and optimism are the most influential factors" (p.17)
"Trust, risk, relative advantage, social influence, and perceived behavioral control influence the decision to adopt cryptocurrency" (p.18)
"The factors affecting cryptocurrency adoption are interdependent" (p.16)
"Our study provides cryptocurrency stakeholders with an improved understanding of the topic" (p.2)

filepath: /Users/v/solomonresearch/blockchain sna litrev/PDFs/Keshk et al. - 2020 - A Privacy-Preserving-Framework-Based Blockchain and Deep Learning for Protecting Smart Power Network.pdf
findings:
- Two-level privacy framework achieves 96.27% accuracy and 2.93% FAR on power system dataset; 99.8% accuracy and 0.01% FAR on UNSW-NB15 dataset (p. 7-8)
- Framework requires ~73 seconds to process 14,000 data observations, comparable to PPAD-CPS technique (p. 8)
- VAE model achieves 92.1% accuracy on power system dataset and 99.8% accuracy on UNSW-NB15 dataset (p. 6)
- Enhanced PoW technique successfully verifies data integrity and detects altered records (p. 8)
gaps:
- Existing conventional security solutions may not be fit-for-purpose in smart grid environment (p. 1)
- Current privacy preservation approaches cannot fully protect against both data poisoning and inference attacks (p. 3)
- Need for balanced privacy protection and data utility in smart power networks (p. 2)
methodologies:
- Enhanced Proof of Work (ePoW) blockchain technique for data integrity (p. 4-5)
- Variational AutoEncoder (VAE) for data transformation (p. 4-5)
- Long Short Term Memory (LSTM) deep learning for anomaly detection (p. 5)
- Two public datasets used: Power System and UNSW-NB15 (p. 6)
- 5-fold cross-validation for performance evaluation (p. 6)
limitations:
- Framework only tested on two datasets (p. 8)
- Need to evaluate scalability and utility on different real-world datasets (p. 8)
- Computational processing time could be improved (p. 7-8)
- Limited to smart power network applications (p. 8)

filename: Kim et al. - 2021 - Autonomous operation control of IoT blockchain networks.pdf
filepath: /Users/v/solomonresearch/blockchain sna litrev/PDFs/Kim et al. - 2021 - Autonomous operation control of IoT blockchain networks.pdf
abstract_text:
Internet of Things (IoT) networks are typically composed of many sensors and actuators.
The operation controls for robots in smart factories or drones produce a massive volume of data
that requires high reliability. A blockchain architecture can be used to build highly reliable IoT
networks. The shared ledger and open data validation among users guarantee extremely high data
security. However, current blockchain technology has limitations for its overall application across IoT
networks. Because ...
findings:
- Deep clustering maintains >60% intra-cluster transaction ratio for 12 hours in IoT blockchain networks (p.9)
- GNN-based node classification reduces memory requirements - sensor nodes store only 21 dApps vs theoretical 1000 (p.12)
- 100% of fake transactions detected and excluded using Proof of Elapsed Time consensus (p.13)
- Proposed methods show better robustness compared to k-means and GA clustering (p.14)
gaps:
- Current blockchain technology limitations for IoT networks due to high computing power requirements (p.1)
- Need for efficient dApp spreading methods linked to dynamic clustering in IoT environments (p.12)
- Lack of lightweight blockchain solutions for resource-constrained IoT devices (p.2)
methodologies:
- Deep clustering using CNN with 5 convolutional layers for network configuration (p.8)
- GNN-based node classification for dApp spreading optimization (p.6-7)
- Docker-based cloud testbed with 100 VMs for experimental validation (p.7-8)
- Attack agent simulation for security validation (p.12-13)
limitations:
- Limited validation due to computing power constraints of simulation system (p.13)
- Homogeneous VMs cannot fully reflect actual IoT node operations (p.13)
- Limited to 100 nodes in experiments due to cloud system constraints (p.13)
- Network size limited to 100m radius circle for simulations (p.10)
abstract_supported_sentences:
- "Internet of Things (IoT) networks are typically composed of many sensors and actuators."

- "Current blockchain technology has limitations for its overall application across IoT networks."
- "A lightweight blockchain provides practical blockchain availability over IoT networks."

"The proposed deep clustering derives better robustness compared to successive k-means clustering and GA (Genetic Algorithm)-based clustering." (p.14)
"The computation results of IoT node clustering illustrate the practical applicability of deep clustering to IoT blockchain networks." (p.14)

filename: Kuo et al. - 2020 - Privacy-preserving model learning on a blockchain network-of-networks.pdf
filepath: /Users/v/solomonresearch/blockchain sna litrev/PDFs/Kuo et al. - 2020 - Privacy-preserving model learning on a blockchain network-of-networks.pdf
abstract_text:
Objective: To facilitate clinical/genomic/biomedical research, constructing generalizable predictive models us-
ing cross-institutional methods while protecting privacy is imperative. However, state-of-the-art methods as-
sume a “ﬂattened” topology, while real-world research networks may consist of “network-of-networks” which
can imply practical issues including training on small data for rare diseases/conditions, prioritizing locally
trained models, and maintaining models for each level of the ...
findings:
- HierarchicalChain outperformed GloreChain for small training data, especially for the THA dataset (p.349)
- Prediction correctness was comparable to GloreChain with similar per-iteration execution time (p.349)
- The method successfully inherited benefits of GloreChain and blockchain advantages while recording models for each network level (p.349)
- Vertical ensemble method showed better performance than horizontal ensemble for combining models across levels (p.349)
gaps:
- Existing methods assume "flattened" network topology while real networks are hierarchical (p.343-344)
- Need for methods that can handle small data for rare conditions while prioritizing local models (p.344)
- Lack of approaches for maintaining models at different hierarchical levels (p.344)
methodologies:
- Level-wise GloreChain decentralized model learning (p.345)
- Blockchain network with MultiChain platform (p.345)
- Proof-of-Hierarchy consensus algorithm (p.346-347)
- Horizontal and vertical ensemble methods for model combination (p.347-348)
- Evaluation on 3 healthcare datasets: Edin, CA, and THA (p.347)
limitations:
- Not tested on non-perfect tree topologies (p.351)
- Limited evaluation on data with large number of covariates or missing data (p.351)
- Does not address advanced privacy concerns like institutional privacy (p.351)
- Ethical, legal and social implications not fully investigated (p.352)
- Assumes "honest but curious" participants (p.351)

- "We propose a framework to combine level-wise model learning, blockchain-based model dissemination, and a novel hierarchical consensus algorithm for model ensemble."
- "HierarchicalChain improves the predictive correctness for small training datasets"

(p.344)

a token on her source vertex.

token pays a toll to the owner of vertex v, who directs the to...

filename: Li and He - 2023 - Graph Neural Network-Based Bitcoin Transaction Tracking Model.pdf
filepath: /Users/v/solomonresearch/blockchain sna litrev/PDFs/Li and He - 2023 - Graph Neural Network-Based Bitcoin Transaction Tracking Model.pdf
findings:
- Model achieves average AUC of 0.93 and accuracy of 86% on Bitcoin transaction tracking (p. 1)
- BT2 model outperforms baseline models by 25% on AUC and 20% on F1 score (p. 9)

- 2-layer sampling depth provides optimal balance of performance and computational cost (p. 10)
gaps:
- Existing methods cannot efficiently handle large-scale blockchain networks (p. 2-3)
- Current approaches struggle to balance accuracy, time and space costs (p. 1)
- Need for better methods to track anonymous blockchain transactions (p. 1-2)
- Lack of effective node embedding generation for unobserved nodes (p. 1)
methodologies:
- Graph neural network with improved sampling aggregation algorithm (p. 1)
- Inductive aggregation method for node embeddings (p. 1)
- Four aggregators: GCN, MEAN, POOL, LSTM (p. 6)
- Dice similarity for neighbor importance weighting (p. 5)
- Node sampling and negative edge sampling (p. 4-5)
limitations:
- Higher spatiotemporal complexity compared to some baseline models (p. 10)
- LSTM aggregator runs twice as slow as GCN (p. 9)
- Future work needed on spatiotemporal complex network characteristics (p. 11)
- Need to improve network structure learning and negative sample selection (p. 11)

- "The numerical results indicate that the performance of BT2 is better than the state of art methods."

filename: Li and Ning - 2024 - Blockchain Transaction Sharding Algorithm Based on Account-Weighted Graph.pdf
filepath: /Users/v/solomonresearch/blockchain sna litrev/PDFs/Li and Ning - 2024 - Blockchain Transaction Sharding Algorithm Based on Account-Weighted Graph.pdf
findings:
- Proposed AWSA algorithm reduces cross-shard transaction proportion by 78.8% and 78.7% compared to MSA and RSA at sharding granularity of 10 (p.1)
- Average cross-shard transaction delay reduced by 36.1% and 44.5% compared to MSA and RSA (p.1)
- Transaction throughput increased by 93.1% and 122.1% compared to MSA and RSA (p.1)
- AWSA maintains lower average cross-shard number (0.43 vs 1.84) at granularity of 20 (p.11)
- AWSA improves transaction throughput by 140% and 131% compared to MSA and RSA at granularity of 20 (p.12)
gaps:
- Existing sharding strategies ignore relationships between accounts leading to high cross-shard transactions (p.2)
- Need for better transaction sharding strategies to reduce cross-shard transaction proportion (p.2)
- Current blockchain systems have low TPS making them unsuitable for internet-level applications (p.1)
methodologies:
- Account-based transaction sharding model (p.3)
- Account-weighted graph construction using transaction frequency as weights (p.6-7)
- Community discovery algorithm for shard formation (p.7-8)
- Experimental comparison with MSA and RSA algorithms (p.8-12)
- Performance metrics analysis including cross-shard proportion, delay, throughput (p.8-12)
limitations:
- Algorithm suitable only for historical transaction data migration scenarios (p.12)
- Complex execution process though only needs to be performed once (p.12)
- Hot data aggregation issues after sharding need future work (p.13)
- Transaction throughput improvement diminishes at higher shard granularities (p.12)
- Uneven distribution of transaction volumes among shards (p.10-11)
abstract_supported_sentences:
- "Sharding technology is widely regarded as an effective way to solve blockchain scalability limitations"
- "The proposed algorithm is compared with the modular sharding algorithm and the random sharding algorithm under the sharding granularity of 10"
- All performance improvement claims are supported by experimental results
abstract_unsupported_claims: - No major unsupported claims found, though some technical details of implementation are simplified
relevant_body_sentences:
"The AWSA algorithm consistently maintains a lower average cross-shard number of accounts compared to the MSA algorithm and the RSA algorithm" (p.11)
"Experimental results indicate that the AWSA algorithm effectively enhances transaction throughput and improves blockchain performance" (p.12)
"The proposed AWSA algorithm outperforms existing methods in various performance metrics" (p.12)

The abstract provides a fair and accurate representation of the paper's content, methodology and findings, with claims well-supported by experimental results and analysis in the main text.

filename: Liang et al. - 2019 - Evolutionary dynamics of cryptocurrency transaction networks An empirical study.pdf
filepath: /Users/v/solomonresearch/blockchain sna litrev/PDFs/Liang et al. - 2019 - Evolutionary dynamics of cryptocurrency transaction networks An empirical study.pdf
abstract_text:
Cryptocurrency is a well-developed blockchain technology application that is currently a
heated topic throughout the world. The public availability of transaction histories offers an
opportunity to analyze and compare different cryptocurrencies. In this paper, we present a
dynamic network analysis of three representative blockchain-based cryptocurrencies: Bit-
coin, Ethereum, and Namecoin. By analyzing the accumulated network growth, we find that,
unlike most other networks, these cryptocurrency...
findings:
- Cryptocurrency networks do not always follow densification law or constant average degree over time (p.8-9)
- Bitcoin and Ethereum networks show heavy-tailed degree distribution but cannot be perfectly fitted by power law (p.10-11)
- Bitcoin and Ethereum networks exhibit disassortative mixing while Namecoin is non-assortative (p.11-13)
- Only Bitcoin network shows small-world properties based on clustering coefficient analysis (p.12-14)
- Bitcoin and Ethereum LCCs contain large proportion of nodes (60% and 40%) while Namecoin only 5% (p.13-15)
gaps:
- Lack of comprehensive comparison between multiple cryptocurrency networks (p.2)
- Limited understanding of network dynamics over time vs accumulated network analysis (p.9)
- Need for relating network properties to currency characteristics for practical applications (p.16)
methodologies:
- Network growth analysis of accumulated transaction networks (p.6-8)
- Monthly network construction and analysis (p.9)
- Degree distribution analysis using power-law fitting (p.10-11)
- Degree assortativity coefficient calculation (p.10-13)
- Clustering coefficient comparison with random networks (p.12-14)
- LCC size and diameter analysis (p.13-15)
limitations:
- Cannot fully verify if downloaded data matches actual cryptocurrency client data (p.3)
- Analysis period limited to transactions through October 31, 2017 (p.3)
- Difficulty in interpreting small assortativity coefficient values (p.11)
- Network properties only indirectly reflect cryptocurrency competitiveness (p.16)
- Need for future work relating network properties to currency characteristics (p.16)
abstract_supported_sentences:
- "By analyzing the accumulated network growth, we find that, unlike most other networks, these cryptocurrency networks do not always densify over time"
- "Bitcoin and Ethereum networks are heavy-tailed with disassortative mixing"
- "only the former [Bitcoin] can be treated as a small world"

filename: Lin et al. - 2020 - T-EDGE Temporal WEighted MultiDiGraph Embedding for Ethereum Transaction Network Analysis.pdf
filepath: /Users/v/solomonresearch/blockchain sna litrev/PDFs/Lin et al. - 2020 - T-EDGE Temporal WEighted MultiDiGraph Embedding for Ethereum Transaction Network Analysis.pdf
abstract_text:
Recently, graph embedding techniques have been widely used in the analysis of various
networks, but most of the existing embedding methods omit the network dynamics and the
multiplicity of edges, so it is difﬁcult to accurately describe the detailed characteristics of the
transaction networks. Ethereum is a blockchain-based platform supporting smart contracts.
The open nature of blockchain makes the transaction data on Ethereum completely public,
and also brings unprecedented opportunities for t...
findings:
- T-EDGE outperforms baseline embedding methods DeepWalk and node2vec for node classification (p.9)
- Time-dependent walks and edge information are essential for transaction networks (p.9)
- α parameter analysis shows better performance when favoring either temporal or amount information rather than equal weighting (p.10)
- The proposed temporal weighted multidigraph model better represents dynamic transaction networks compared to simple graphs (p.4)
gaps:
- Most existing embedding methods omit network dynamics and multiplicity of edges (p.1)
- Traditional random walk methods don't incorporate temporal information (p.2)
- Limited analytical studies on financial transaction networks due to data privacy (p.1)
- Need for effective methods to analyze large-scale Ethereum transaction data (p.2)
methodologies:
- Temporal Weighted Multidigraph (TWMDG) modeling (p.4)
- Random walk-based graph embedding with temporal restrictions (p.5)
- Skip-gram model for learning node representations (p.7)
- K-order subgraph sampling for data collection (p.8)
- SVM classifier for node classification evaluation (p.9)
limitations:
- Analysis limited to Ethereum transaction network only (p.10)
- Default value of α=0.5 may not be optimal for combining temporal and amount information (p.9)
- Need to investigate more applications beyond phishing detection (p.10)
- Framework needs validation on other temporal/domain-dependent networks (p.10)
abstract_supported_sentences:
- "Most existing embedding methods omit network dynamics and multiplicity of edges"
- "We first model the Ethereum transaction network as a Temporal Weighted Multidigraph"
- "Experimental results demonstrate that T-EDGE outperforms baseline embedding methods"
abstract_unsupported_claims:
- The abstract doesn't explicitly mention limitations or scope constraints
- No mention of the α parameter importance found in results
relevant_body_sentences:
"Our proposed methods T-EDGE, T-EDGE (TBS), T-EDGE (WBS), T-EDGE (TBS+WBS) overwhelmingly outperform DeepWalk and node2vec" (p.9)
"We model the Ethereum transaction records as a Temporal Weighted Multidigraph G = (V, E), where each node represents a unique account and each edge represents a unique Ether transfer transaction" (p.4)
"Experimental results demonstrated the effectiveness of the proposed T-EDGE embedding method, meanwhile indicating that a temporal weighted multidigraph can more comprehensively represent the temporal and financial properties of dynamic transaction networks" (p.10)

filename: Loo and Wong - 2023 - Towards a Conceptual Framework of Using Technology to Support Smart Construction The Case of Modula.pdf
filepath: /Users/v/solomonresearch/blockchain sna litrev/PDFs/Loo and Wong - 2023 - Towards a Conceptual Framework of Using Technology to Support Smart Construction The Case of Modula.pdf
findings:
- Development of BEANiE blockchain platform through 6 versions supporting MiC construction (p.8-15)
- Four-stage conceptual framework for smart construction technology adoption (p.11-13):
  1. Core MiC production and logistics (p.13)
  2. Construction site process integration (p.11-12) 
  3. Worker safety and wellbeing focus (p.12)
  4. Full lifecycle command center integration (p.12-13)
- Blockchain reduces transaction costs by 8.3% in construction projects (p.5)
gaps:
- Limited research on blockchain application specifically for MiC projects (p.2)
- Need for standards and protocols in blockchain construction applications (p.5)
- Lack of understanding on gradual technology adoption approaches for smart construction (p.7)
methodologies:
- Case study approach examining BEANiE platform development (p.7)
- Systematic analysis framework examining:
  - Objectives and scope
  - Stakeholders involved
  - Key outcomes and processes 
  - Blockchain applications
  - Integration with other platforms (p.7-8)
limitations:
- High implementation costs for blockchain systems (p.5)
- Lack of training and skills for new technologies (p.5)
- Limited commercially available construction robotics (p.4)
- Data security and privacy concerns (p.15)
- Need for further research on smart construction practices in G7 countries (p.13)
abstract_supported_sentences:
- "Construction is a major source of carbon emissions..."
- "The ways that technology can help to achieve smart construction...should be further explored"
- Description of four-stage approach matches paper content
- Integration with BIM and other technologies accurately described
abstract_unsupported_claims:
- Abstract overstates the comprehensiveness of the Stage 4 "full construction lifecycle" integration
- Limited evidence provided for claims about improved "overall energy efficiency"
relevant_body_sentences:
"Drawing upon the experience, we propose a generic four-stage approach in understanding and facilitating the adoption of relevant technology towards smart construction" (p.11)
"The lessons learned are being conceptualized as four stages that provide benchmarks and lessons for other cities" (p.13)
"Smart construction will continue to revolutionize the industry" (p.13)

The abstract generally reflects the paper's content well but could better acknowledge implementation challenges and limitations. The four-stage framework is the paper's main contribution and is accurately represented in the abstract.

filename: Mattsson et al. - 2023 - Circulation of a digital community currency.pdf
filepath: /Users/v/solomonresearch/blockchain sna litrev/PDFs/Mattsson et al. - 2023 - Circulation of a digital community currency.pdf
findings:
- Circulation of Sarafu remained modular and geographically localized even during dramatic growth (p.3-4)
- Sub-populations using Sarafu showed diverse economic activities/livelihoods, especially at local level (p.5)
- Short cycles are consistently over-represented in Sarafu networks compared to null models (p.6)
- Network structure shows consistent degree disassortativity across sub-populations (p.6-7)
- Community-based savings groups and faith leaders played key prominent roles (p.8-9)
- Women's participation and early adopters showed higher network centrality (p.8-9)
gaps:
- Limited understanding of temporal/sequential information in monetary flow networks (p.9)
- Need for methods to analyze network cycles and log-normal distributions with Pareto tails (p.9)
- Gap in understanding network-structural regularities across different currency systems (p.9)
methodologies:
- Network flow analysis using Infomap algorithm for community detection (p.3-4)
- Cycle counting compared to null models (ER and RD networks) (p.6)
- Network assortativity measures for structural correlations (p.6-7)
- PageRank and weighted PageRank for centrality analysis (p.7-8)
- Linear regression (OLS and Elastic Net) for analyzing user features (p.8-9)
limitations:
- Study considers only aggregated circulation over full period, losing temporal information (p.9)
- Current methods lack ability to capture dynamic representations of transaction processes (p.9)
- Need for measures of fidelity between temporal and static network representations (p.9)
- Limited ability to distinguish between Pareto and log-normal distributions in weighted degree analysis (p.12-13)
- Data anonymization prevented analysis at more granular geographic levels (p.5)
abstract_supported_sentences:
- "Circulation is the characteristic feature of successful currency systems"
- "Network flow analysis reveals that circulation was highly modular, geographically localized, and occurring among users with diverse livelihoods"
- "Network cycle analysis supports the intuitive notion that circulation requires cycles"
- "The sub-networks underlying circulation are consistently degree disassortative"
- "Community-based institutions often take on the role of local hubs"
abstract_unsupported_claims: - None found - all major claims are well supported by evidence in the paper
relevant_body_sentences:
"The circulation of Sarafu was highly modular in that activity occurred almost exclusively within distinct sub-populations" (p.4)
"We conclude that the circulation of Sarafu was geographically localized over the observed period" (p.5)
"Most notably, we see a mix of the different economic activities within the largest second-level sub-populations" (p.5)
"Short cycles are a prominent network connectivity pattern in the circulation of Sarafu, and perhaps of (community) currencies more generally" (p.6)
"We find substantial disassortativity in degree across nearly all sub-networks" (p.6)

filename: Mssassi and Abou El Kalam - 2024 - Game Theory-Based Incentive Design for Mitigating Malicious Behavior in Blockchain Networks.pdf

abstract_text:
This paper presents an innovative incentive model that utilizes graph and game theories to
address the issue of node incentives in decentralized blockchain networks such as EVM blockchains.
The lack of incentives for nodes within EVM networks gives rise to potential weaknesses that might
be used for various purposes, such as broadcasting fake transactions or withholding blocks. This
affects the overall trust and integrity of the network. To address this issue, the current study offers a
network ...
findings:
- Demonstrated linear relationship between percentage of malicious nodes and packet loss (p. 24-25)
- False positive/negative rates declined over successive rounds showing improved accuracy (p. 25)
- Network showed increased resilience to Sybil attacks over rounds (p. 26)
- Convergence time for trust matrices decreased over rounds indicating improved efficiency (p. 26)
- Trust matrix approach successfully incentivized honest node behavior through reward mechanisms (p. 17-18)
gaps:
- Lack of incentives for non-mining nodes in EVM networks (p. 1)
- Need for better understanding of how to effectively incentivize nodes to align individual gains with network health (p. 1)
- Gap in optimizing node evaluation due to potential impact of malicious credit evaluations (p. 27)
methodologies:
- Graph theory modeling of blockchain network nodes (p. 11-13)
- Game theoretic framework for analyzing node interactions (p. 13-15)
- Trust matrix representation for tracking node reputation (p. 15-17)
- Depth-first search algorithm for calculating node weights (p. 20-21)
- Simulation testing across different network types and sizes (p. 23-24)
limitations:
- Model requires minimum of 3f+1 nodes where f is number of faulty nodes (p. 15)
- Current approach focused only on executor nodes, not mining nodes (p. 7)
- Need for further research in node evaluation optimization (p. 27)
- Need to explore cross-chain compatibility and interoperability (p. 27)
- Privacy concerns requiring future work on zero-knowledge proofs (p. 27)
abstract_supported_sentences:
- "This paper presents an innovative incentive model that utilizes graph and game theories to address the issue of node incentives in decentralized blockchain networks such as EVM blockchains."
- "The simulations validated the model's efficacy in addressing fraudulent transactions and emphasized its scalability, security, and fairness benefits."

"The model demonstrates a linear relationship between the percentage of malicious nodes and the packet loss." (p. 24)
"With each progressive round, the number of successful attacks decreased, emphasizing the effectiveness of our matrix-based representation and reward mechanism." (p. 26)

abstract_text:
This study investigates the digital transformation trends in the Korean fashion indus-
try over the past decade, focusing on business models, processes, services, prod-
ucts, and customers. Using bibliometric and big data analyses, we examined articles 
from journals listed on the Korea Citation Index (KCI) from 2014 to 2023. It was revealed 
that the five factors are not independent but are complementary and intercon-
nected. Keyword frequency and network analysis revealed key themes, includ-
i...
findings:
- Digital transformation research in fashion increased significantly from 2014-2023, peaking in 2022 with 74 articles (p. 8-9)
- Five factors (business models, processes, services, products, customers) are interconnected rather than independent (p. 19)
- Keywords like "metaverse," "COVID-19," "VR," "experience," and "MZ generation" emerged as key themes across factors (p. 19)
- Traditional clothing ("hanbok") integration with digital platforms emerged as significant for services and products (p. 20)
- Content and experiential value are crucial for engaging MZ generation consumers (p. 21)
gaps:
- Limited analysis of specific digital technologies' implementation (p. 6)
- Lack of comprehensive analysis centered on digital transformation rather than specific phenomena (p. 2)
- Need for broader analysis beyond luxury brands and specific digital technologies (p. 6)
- Gap in understanding consumer responses to digital transformation (p. 21)
methodologies:
- Bibliometric analysis of Korean academic journals 2014-2023 (p. 7)
- Keyword frequency analysis using TF and TF-IDF (p. 8)
- Network analysis using centrality measures (p. 8)
- Classification by two fashion marketing experts (p. 8)
- Analysis of 249 articles across five factors (p. 8)
limitations:
- Relies only on academic journal titles, abstracts, and keywords (p. 21)
- Focus on Korean context may not reflect global trends (p. 21-22)
- Limited data sources excluding blogs, forums, consumer reviews (p. 21)
- Need for more systematic analysis framework like TCCM (p. 21)
- Lack of topic modeling analysis (p. 21)
- Need for comparative studies incorporating international data (p. 22)

findings:
- Blockchain has drawbacks including high energy consumption, scalability issues, and lack of support for micro-transactions (p.3)
- Block Lattice and DAG provide better support for micro-transactions with reduced carbon footprint compared to Blockchain (p.4)
- P2P energy trading framework still depends fundamentally on electrical infrastructure adaptation regardless of technology choice (p.5)
- Current regulatory frameworks are inadequate for P2P energy trading implementations (p.4-5)
- Non-government backed cryptocurrencies pose challenges for real-world implementation due to volatility (p.5)
gaps:
- Lack of digital and electrical platforms to facilitate P2P energy trading (p.3)
- Missing regulatory framework for tax and grid fees in P2P energy trading (p.3)
- Need for adaptation of distributed ledger technologies to follow local regulations (p.4)
- Gap between information layer solutions and electrical infrastructure requirements (p.5)
methodologies:
- Comparative analysis of distributed ledger architectures: Blockchain, Block Lattice, and DAG (p.1-4)
- Review and analysis of existing P2P energy trading initiatives (p.2)
- Analysis of technical and regulatory challenges (p.3-5)
limitations:
- Dependency on macrogrid as platform provider for inter-microgrid transactions (p.4)
- High carbon footprint and energy consumption requirements (p.4-5)

- Volatility issues with non-government backed cryptocurrencies (p.5)

more information, since they account for both the graph topology

there are varying definitions...

filename: Pele and Mazurencu-Marinescu-Pele - 2019 - Metcalfe's law and log-period power laws in the cryptocurrencies market.pdf
filepath: /Users/v/solomonresearch/blockchain sna litrev/PDFs/Pele and Mazurencu-Marinescu-Pele - 2019 - Metcalfe's law and log-period power laws in the cryptocurrencies market.pdf
abstract_text:
In this paper the authors investigate the statistical properties of some cryptocurrencies by 
using three layers of analysis: alpha-stable distributions, Metcalfe’s law and the bubble 
behaviour through the LPPL modelling. The results show, in the medium to long-run, 
the validity of Metcalfe's law (the value of a network is proportional to the square of the 
number of connected users of the system) for the evaluation of cryptocurrencies; however, 
in the short-run, the validity of Metcalfe’s la...
findings:
- Cryptocurrencies exhibit large departures from normality with high uncertainty levels shown by stability indexes (p.21)
- Metcalfe's law is valid for Bitcoin in medium-long run but questionable in short-run (p.21)
- Clear pattern of inconsistency over time questions Metcalfe's law validity for Bitcoin across different data windows (p.21)
- Strong correlation between network size and market price may indicate mimetic investor behavior (p.21)
- LPPL models successfully predicted regime switching for Bitcoin and CRIX index bubbles (p.19-20)
- Bidirectional causality found between Bitcoin price and network size (p.17)
gaps:
- Need for comprehensive statistical analysis combining alpha-stable distributions, Metcalfe's law and LPPL modeling (p.4)
- Limited research on causality between price and network size for cryptocurrencies (p.15)
- Gap in understanding short-term vs long-term validity of Metcalfe's law (p.21)
methodologies:
- Alpha-stable distributions to analyze heavy-tails (p.5-6)
- Generalized Metcalfe's law modeling (p.5-6)
- Log-Periodic Power Law (LPPL) models (p.6)
- Granger causality tests (p.16)
- Cointegration analysis (p.15)
- VAR modeling (p.16)
limitations:
- Analysis limited to cryptocurrencies with at least 2 years of daily data (p.7)
- Unique addresses as imperfect proxy for network users (p.10)
- LPPL models don't fully reproduce characteristic oscillations in actual data (p.20)
- Stationarity assumption in cointegration analysis contradicts LPPL bubble existence (p.22)
abstract_supported_sentences:
"The results show, in the medium to long-run, the validity of Metcalfe's law for the evaluation of cryptocurrencies; however, in the short-run, the validity of Metcalfe's law for Bitcoin is questionable."
"According to the bidirectional causality between the price and the network size, the expected price increase is a driver for more investors to join the Bitcoin network"
"The authors then used LPPL models to capture the behaviour of cryptocurrencies exchange rates during an endogenous bubble and to predict the most probable time of the regime switching"
abstract_unsupported_claims: None found - all major claims are supported by evidence in the paper
relevant_body_sentences:
"The main conclusion of this paper is that Metcalfe's law may be valid in the long-run, however in the short-run, on various data regimes, its validity is highly debatable." (p.22)
"Based on the Granger causality tests, one can deduce the existence of a unidirectional causal relationship from the Bitcoin's prices to the size of the network" (p.16)
"The best fit for the CRIX index was given by the model estimated for the period January 1st 2016 – December 30th 2017, for which the estimated critical time was exactly the date of local maximum, January 7th 2018" (p.20)

findings:

- Code reuse is common practice with well-commented source code (p.16)

- Transaction counts and balances follow power-law distributions but are uncorrelated (p.16)

- Most used contracts are mainly financial/token contracts with more complex metrics (p.17)
gaps:
- Limited research on comprehensive empirical analysis of Ethereum smart contracts (p.2)
- Lack of specific tools for analyzing Solidity source code metrics (p.4)
- Need for analysis of contracts without available source code (p.17-18)
- Gap in understanding internal transactions between contracts (p.18)
methodologies:
- Collection and analysis of 10,174 smart contract source codes from Etherscan.io (p.4)
- Statistical analysis of contract parameters: names, compiler versions, transactions, balances (p.5-7)
- Code metrics analysis: volume metrics, contract-oriented metrics (p.7-9)
- Detailed analysis of top 20 most used contracts (p.9-15)
- Cross-correlation analysis between metrics and usage indicators (p.15)
limitations:
- Analysis limited to contracts with available source code (p.17-18)
- Focus only on verified contracts from Etherscan.io (p.4)
- Need for analysis of internal transactions between contracts (p.18)

- Limited analysis of library usage and contract interactions (p.18)
- Need for wider correlation analysis (p.18)

limitations:

filename: Provenzano and Baggio - 2021 - Complexity traits and synchrony of cryptocurrencies price dynamics.pdf
filepath: /Users/v/solomonresearch/blockchain sna litrev/PDFs/Provenzano and Baggio - 2021 - Complexity traits and synchrony of cryptocurrencies price dynamics.pdf
abstract_text:
In this study, we characterized the dynamics and analyzed the degree of synchro-
nization of the time series of daily closing prices and volumes in US$ of three 
cryptocurrencies, Bitcoin, Ethereum, and Litecoin, over the period September 
1,2015–March 31, 2020. Time series were first mapped into a complex network by 
the horizontal visibility algorithm in order to revel the structure of their temporal 
characters and dynamics. Then, the synchrony of the time series was investigated to 
determin...
findings:
- BTC and LTC exhibit correlated stochastic behavior while ETH shows uncorrelated stochastic (random) behavior (p.952)
- Volume dynamics are more predictable than prices for all three cryptocurrencies (p.952)
- Strong similarity found in community structure between currencies, indicating similar cyclical patterns (p.952)
- Limited synchrony between cryptocurrencies, but higher synchronization after market collapse events (p.950-951)
- All λ exponents calculated are above the frontier λc=0.405, indicating none of the series is chaotic (p.949)
gaps:
- Limited application of HVG algorithm to cryptocurrency price dynamics, with only one prior study focused on Bitcoin (p.943)
- Need for better understanding of potential interactions among bubble periods within cryptocurrency markets (p.944)
- Lack of research on synchronization between different cryptocurrencies' price movements (p.944)
methodologies:
- Horizontal visibility graph (HVG) algorithm to map time series into networks (p.944-945)
- Hodrick-Prescott filter to remove short-term fluctuations (p.944)
- Community structure analysis using modularity index (p.947)
- Synchrony analysis using mutual information theory (p.947-948)
- Time series transformation into symbolic sequences (p.947)
limitations:
- Research period bounded by shorter dataset available for Ethereum (p.944)
- Deviations shown in tail of distribution due to finite nature of series (p.949)
- Analysis focused only on three major cryptocurrencies (p.943)
- Limited time horizon from September 2015 to March 2020 (p.944)
abstract_supported_sentences:
- "Time series were first mapped into a complex network by the horizontal visibility algorithm"
- "Findings reveal similar complex structures for the three virtual currencies in terms of number and internal composition of communities"
- "The study of synchrony between the time series investigated displayed a different degree of synchronization between the three cryptocurrencies before and after a collapse event"
abstract_unsupported_claims:
- The abstract does not explicitly mention limitations of the study
- The abstract truncates mid-sentence, leaving out complete details about exponential distributions

"The investigation carried out revealed a higher synchrony in the behavior of the cryptocurrencies investigated after a collapse event" (p.952)
"Volume dynamics resulted more predictable than prices" (p.952)

abstract_text:
This systematic review aims to examine how blockchain technology enhances security and 
trust in mobile commerce transactions, focusing on its application in mobile payments. The 
study employs a comprehensive methodology, utilizing the Scopus database to gather rele-
vant literature published between 2018 and 2024. Using carefully selected keywords related 
to blockchain, mobile payments, and security, the initial search yielded 229 records, which 
were subsequently filtered using the PRISMA fr...
findings:
- Blockchain technology addresses critical issues in mobile payments including high storage costs and processing latency (p. 141)
- Blockchain-based self-sovereign identity (SSI) enhances efficiency and privacy of KYC processes (p. 141)
- Secure lightweight wallets and Merkle Hash Trees improve transaction security and speed (p. 141)
- Blockchain enables offline transactions using Bluetooth in areas with poor connectivity (p. 142)
- Annual publication growth rate of 49.13% indicates rapidly increasing research interest (p. 137)
- Four main thematic clusters identified: wallets, financial, blockchain, and mobile (p. 139-140)
gaps:
- Need for scalability solutions to handle high transaction volumes (p. 144)
- Integration challenges with existing mobile payment infrastructure (p. 144)
- Regulatory frameworks need development for blockchain financial innovations (p. 144)
- Research needed on improving energy efficiency of blockchain systems (p. 144)
- User interface improvements needed for wider adoption (p. 144)
methodologies:
- Systematic literature review using Scopus database (p. 136)
- PRISMA framework for screening records (p. 136)
- VOSviewer software for bibliometric analysis (p. 136-137)
- Thematic clustering analysis (p. 139-140)
- Callon centrality and density metrics for cluster analysis (p. 139)
limitations:
- Scalability remains a significant challenge (p. 135)
- Integration with existing systems poses technical challenges (p. 135)
- High energy consumption concerns (p. 144)
- User adoption barriers due to complex interfaces (p. 144)
- Regulatory uncertainty (p. 144)

filename: S. He et al. - 2018 - A Social-Network-Based Cryptocurrency Wallet-Management Scheme.pdf
filepath: /Users/v/solomonresearch/blockchain sna litrev/PDFs/S. He et al. - 2018 - A Social-Network-Based Cryptocurrency Wallet-Management Scheme.pdf
abstract_text:
Effective cryptocurrency key management has become an urgent requirement for modern
cryptocurrency. Although a large body of cryptocurrency wallet-management schemes has been proposed,
they are mostly constructed for speciﬁc application scenarios and often suffer from weak security. In this
paper, we propose a more effective, usable, and secure cryptocurrency wallet-management system based on
semi-trusted social networks, therein allowing users to collaborate with involved parties to achieve som...
findings:
- Proposed a cryptocurrency wallet management system based on semi-trusted social networks (p.1)
- Implemented protocols for secure storage, portable login, no-password authentication, key delegation, and wallet recovery (p.7-8)
- Performance analysis showed minimal overhead with time delays of only milliseconds (p.7661)
- System achieved IND-CDBA security based on underlying HIKE scheme security (p.7660)
gaps:
- Gap between human memory limitations and complex cryptocurrency key structures (p.7655)
- Lack of effective and secure key management mechanisms for cryptocurrency wallets (p.7655)
- Most existing wallet schemes are built for specific scenarios and have weak security (p.7654)
methodologies:
- Identity-based hierarchical key-insulated encryption scheme (p.7657)
- Shamir secret sharing scheme for key backup (p.7658)
- Digital signature scheme for authentication (p.7658)
- Performance evaluation using Java Pairing-Based Cryptography library (p.7661)
- Security analysis using IND-CDBA security model (p.7660)
limitations:
- Assumes secure running environment with no malware or keyloggers (p.7656)
- Limited to 2-level HIKE scheme implementation (p.7661)
- Requires trusted social network participants for key recovery (p.7659)
- No formal proof of security against all possible attack vectors
abstract_supported_sentences:

"The system enjoys the properties of security-enhanced storage, portable login on different devices, no-password authentication, flexible key delegation, blind wallet recovery, etc." (p.7661)

The abstract generally reflects the paper's content well but could better specify the security model used and acknowledge some key limitations. The technical implementation details and performance results support most abstract claims.

filename: Said et al. - 2021 - Detailed analysis of Ethereum network on transaction behavior, community structure and link predicti.pdf
filepath: /Users/v/solomonresearch/blockchain sna litrev/PDFs/Said et al. - 2021 - Detailed analysis of Ethereum network on transaction behavior, community structure and link predicti.pdf
abstract_text:
Ethereum, the second-largest cryptocurrency after Bitcoin, has attracted wide atten-
tion in the last few years and accumulated significant transaction records. However,
the underlying Ethereum network structure is still relatively unexplored. Also, very
few attempts have been made to perform link predictability on the Ethereum transac-
tions network. This paper presents a Detailed Analysis of the Ethereum Network on
Transaction Behavior, Community Structure, and Link Prediction (DANET) frame-
w...
findings:
- Most Ethereum addresses (88%) are associated with less than 10 transactions each (p.12)
- Distribution of Ether is more associated with in-degrees rather than out-degrees (p.17-18)
- Network contains 5 major communities with one central community containing influential addresses covering ~30% of network (p.18)
- VGAE model achieved 87.6% and 91.59% AUC on two test networks for link prediction (p.18)
- 96% of addresses' current balance is less than 10 Ether (p.15)
- Less than 1 Ether has been received by 53% of transactions (p.15)
gaps:
- Limited research on Ethereum network analysis compared to Bitcoin (p.2)
- Lack of detailed analyses of network community structures in Ethereum (p.3)
- Few attempts at link prediction on Ethereum transaction networks (p.1)
- Bitcoin data analysis methods cannot be directly applied to Ethereum due to different protocols (p.2)
methodologies:
- DANET framework with 4 modules: Data Management, Transaction Behavior Analysis, Community Structure Analysis, Link Prediction Analysis (p.3)
- Louvain algorithm for community detection (p.9-10)
- Variational Graph Auto-Encoders (VGAE) for link prediction (p.10-11)
- Gini coefficient analysis for wealth distribution (p.15-16)
limitations:
- Analysis limited to data from 2015-2019 (p.9)
- Memory limitations required using only 20 days of transactions for link prediction analysis (p.11)
- Study lacks analysis of temporal properties evolution (p.19)
- Does not investigate combined community detection and link prediction (p.19)
- More recent data could be analyzed to study network evolution (p.19)
abstract_supported_sentences:
- "Ethereum, the second-largest cryptocurrency after Bitcoin, has attracted wide attention in the last few years and accumulated significant transaction records."
- "This paper presents a Detailed Analysis of the Ethereum Network on Transaction Behavior, Community Structure, and Link Prediction (DANET) framework"
- "The link prediction experimental results demonstrate the superiority of outstanding prediction accuracy on Ethereum networks"
abstract_unsupported_claims:

"The experimental results show some useful statistical characteristics of the Ethereum network in terms of the distribution of active addresses, traffic of Ether history per address, and the degree distribution" (p.3)
"The model showed impressive prediction accuracy on the link prediction task" (p.20)

findings:

gaps:
- Need for improved security in intelligent systems with weak authentication (p. 2)
- Limitations of traditional centralized access control strategies (p. 2-3)
- Lack of efficient private data storage solutions for IoT applications (p. 3)
methodologies:
- Deep learning models including LSTM and RNN (p. 3-4)
- Hidden Markov Models for security situation assessment (p. 7)
- SSIPN (Scalable Security Information Propagation Network) (p. 11-12)
- Block chain-based storage mechanisms (p. 3)
- Hash chain-based message transmission (p. 7-8)
limitations:
- Potential single point of failure risks in centralized systems (p. 2-3)
- Storage capacity constraints of smart devices (p. 3)
- Security vulnerabilities during data transmission (p. 2)
- Scalability challenges with traditional storage solutions (p. 2)

filename: Soundararajan et al. - 2022 - Interleaved Honeypot-Framing Model with Secure MAC Policies for Wireless Sensor Networks.pdf

findings:
- Proposed WIHFM achieves 10-14% better performance compared to existing techniques (p. 1)
- True positive rate between 89.8% and 99.6% compared to 91.6-97.6% for existing techniques (p. 19-20)
- Minimal routing delay between 102-127ms compared to 153-160ms for other techniques (p. 20)
- Computation overhead of 12.6-14.9% compared to up to 16.8% for other approaches (p. 20-21)
- Secure throughput probability rate maintained at 0.96 even with maximal node movement (p. 21)
- AES/ECCDS achieves minimum response time of 485ms compared to 638-780ms for other suites (p. 22)
gaps:
- Lack of novel secure MAC models for WSNs (p. 4)
- Need for distributed honeypot engines in wireless networks (p. 4) 
- Absence of interleaved honeypot frame solutions (p. 4)
- Limited open traps in WSN security (p. 4)
- Lack of node-centric IDS engines (p. 26)
methodologies:
- On-Demand Acyclic Network Connectivity model (ODAC) (p. 4-5)
- Interleaved Honeypot-Framing Traps (p. 5)
- Distributed Neighbor-based Honeypot Engines (p. 5)
- Secure Hashing with Random Interleaving procedures (p. 5)
- NS-3.35 simulation with up to 300 sensor nodes (p. 17)
- AES encryption and ECCDS authentication (p. 22)
limitations:
- Uncertain IHF latency as network dynamics change (p. 23)
- Variable honeypot response time with network changes (p. 23)
- Static limitations requiring dynamic programming solutions (p. 23)
- Need for improved trap management policies for application-specific platforms (p. 23)
- Requires environmental and configuration validation for optimal performance in real-time (p. 23)

filename: T. He et al. - 2018 - Parallel Community Detection Based on Distance Dynamics for Large-Scale Network.pdf
filepath: /Users/v/solomonresearch/blockchain sna litrev/PDFs/T. He et al. - 2018 - Parallel Community Detection Based on Distance Dynamics for Large-Scale Network.pdf
findings:
- P-Attractor algorithm achieves similar clustering quality to traditional Attractor while being much faster for large networks (p.42784-42785)
- Execution time on 4 threads and 32 threads are around 10 hours and 2 hours respectively for large networks (p.42776)
- The improved distance dynamics model reduces computation time by ~10% compared to traditional model (p.42787)
- Graph partitioning method successfully divides large networks while maintaining neighbor structure (p.42786)
- Pre-judgment coefficient effectively addresses slow convergence issues (p.42781-42782)
gaps:
- Traditional community detection algorithms struggle with large-scale networks (0.1-1 billion edges) due to hardware limits and high time complexity (p.42775)
- Need for high-speed community detection algorithms that maintain clustering quality (p.42775)
- Slow convergence problem in traditional distance dynamics model needs to be addressed (p.42780)
methodologies:
- Graph partitioning method to divide large networks into sub-networks (p.42776)
- Improved distance dynamics model with convergence threshold and pre-judgment coefficient (p.42780-42782)
- Parallel processing approach using multiple threads (p.42783)
- Three-phase community detection process: graph partitioning, parallel dynamic interaction, community detection (p.42783)
limitations:
- Performance depends on network structure and degree distribution (p.42788)
- Relative speedup increase diminishes with higher thread counts (p.42788)
- Currently only works for static networks, not dynamic or high-order networks (p.42788)
- Some trade-off between computation speed and clustering accuracy with convergence threshold parameter (p.42782)
abstract_supported_sentences:
- "Data mining task is a challenge on finding a high-quality community structure from large-scale networks"
- "The distance dynamics model was proved to be active on regular-size network community"
- "Our algorithm first developed a graph partitioning method to divide large network into lots of sub-networks"
- "The execution time on 4 threads and 32 threads are around 10 and 2 h, respectively"
abstract_unsupported_claims: - The claim that the algorithm is "potential to discover community from a billion-scale network" is not fully demonstrated in the results

- "Our proposed algorithm contributes to handle community discovering problem for large-scale network within acceptable computation time" (p.42776)
- "The graph partitioning method guarantees the feasibility of parallel dynamic interaction process" (p.42776)
- "Convergence threshold and pre-judgment coefficient are designed for solving the slow-convergence problem" (p.42776)

findings:

methodologies:

- MALLET-based topic modeling for identifying topic-specific networks (p.196502)

limitations:

filename: Vasudevan et al. - 2025 - Information diffusion in referral networks an empirical investigation of the crypto asset landscape.pdf
filepath: /Users/v/solomonresearch/blockchain sna litrev/PDFs/Vasudevan et al. - 2025 - Information diffusion in referral networks an empirical investigation of the crypto asset landscape.pdf
abstract_text:
In the last decades, crypto assets have become particularly popular in financial markets. 
However, public awareness of the crypto asset landscape is rather limited, and usually 
associated with sensationalized media coverage of a handful of cryptocurrencies. Moreo-
ver, while users of crypto assets primarily collect information on Internet, there is a limited 
understanding of the relational (online) structures supporting the diffusion of information 
about these financial products. Therefore, ...
findings:
- Social media and news channel sites play key role in information diffusion while market/trading sites signal innovation adoption (p. S51-52)
- Websites of much-sensationalized cryptocurrencies are not key in information referral networks (p. S51)
- Social media websites are enablers but not mature hubs due to low connectivity (p. S51-52)
- Low assortativity and average degree indicate crypto assets are in awareness stage (p. S53)
- Network density (0.001) and average degree (0.927) are low, indicating limited information diffusion (p. S50)
gaps:
- Limited understanding of relational online structures supporting crypto asset information diffusion (p. S41)
- Lack of research on full scope of crypto asset landscape beyond just cryptocurrencies (p. S42)
- Need for systematic analysis of social media channels' role in crypto adoption (p. S53)
methodologies:
- Multi-method approach combining web scraping, web analytics, and social network analysis (p. S41)
- Data collection from coinmarketcap API for top 200 assets by market cap (p. S45)
- Web analytics data from SimilarWeb API (p. S45-46)
- Social network analysis of referral networks using centrality measures (p. S48)
limitations:
- Limited to free version of SimilarWeb with max 5 website referrals (p. S54)
- Cross-sectional rather than longitudinal data (p. S54)
- No analysis of causal relationships between network centrality and web analytics (p. S54)
- Missing analytic data for 54 websites out of initial 227 (p. S49)
abstract_supported_sentences:
- "By adopting a multi-method approach consisting of web scraping, web analytics, and social network analysis"
- "Our results show that social media and news channel sites play a key role in the information diffusion process"
- "cryptocurrencies' websites do not seem key in the referral network"
abstract_unsupported_claims:
- The abstract does not explicitly acknowledge the study's limitations
- The claim about "limited understanding" of relational structures could be better qualified
relevant_body_sentences:
"Our analysis shows that the most central websites in this network are market sites, which indicates that adopters are exposed to information by chance and through ill-defined exploration" (p. S53)
"Low assortativity and average degree indicate that crypto assets are in their awareness stage, where the public attention to the existence of these assets is beginning to expand" (p. S53)
"The network density (proportion of the total network ties over the total number of possible ties) is 0.001 and the average degree (average number of connections a node has in a network) is 0.927" (p. S50)

filename: Wang et al. - 2020 - Framework and algorithms for identifying honest blocks in blockchain.pdf
filepath: /Users/v/solomonresearch/blockchain sna litrev/PDFs/Wang et al. - 2020 - Framework and algorithms for identifying honest blocks in blockchain.pdf
abstract_text:
Blockchain technology gains more and more attention in the past decades and has been
applied in many areas. The main bottleneck for the development and application of block-
chain is its limited scalability. Blockchain with directed acyclic graph structure (BlockDAG) is
proposed in order to alleviate the scalability problem. One of the key technical problems in
BlockDAG is the identification of honest blocks which are very important for establishing a
stable and invulnerable total order of all t...
findings:
- MaxCord framework successfully converts honest block identification into a maximum k-independent set problem (p.3-4)
- MAXCORD-IFA algorithm outperforms PHANTOM especially with heavy attack power (p.10-11)
- Discord measurement between blocks effectively distinguishes honest vs dishonest blocks (p.4-5)
- Parameter α=0.9 provides optimal balance of precision, recall and runtime for MAXCORD-IFA (p.9)
- MAXCORD-IFA maintains high precision while slightly sacrificing recall compared to other methods (p.11-12)
gaps:
- Lack of real BlockDAG data for evaluation (p.7-8)
- Need to investigate general MaxCord-(k,d) model beyond special cases (p.12)
- Unclear influence of different algorithms on subsequent block ordering (p.12)
- Limited understanding of transaction fee allocation in BlockDAG (p.12)
methodologies:
- Novel discord measurement between blocks (p.3-4)
- MaxCord framework converting to k-independent set problem (p.5-6)
- Three algorithms: MAXCORD-EXACT, MAXCORD-GREEDY, MAXCORD-IFA (p.6-8)
- Simulation of BlockDAG datasets using probabilistic model (p.7-8)
- Comparative evaluation against PHANTOM algorithm (p.10-11)
limitations:
- Only evaluated on simulated data, not real BlockDAG systems (p.7-8)
- PHANTOM comparison limited to small-scale cases due to computational constraints (p.10)
- Only investigated two special cases of MaxCord framework (p.12)
- Block ordering implications not fully analyzed (p.12)
- Limited to specific BlockDAG connection model (p.12-13)
abstract_supported_sentences:
- "Blockchain with directed acyclic graph structure (BlockDAG) is proposed in order to alleviate the scalability problem."
- "This paper presents a novel universal framework based on graph theory, called MaxCord, for identifying the honest blocks in BlockDAG."
- "The extensive comparisons between proposed algorithms and the existing method were conducted on the simulated BlockDAG data"
abstract_unsupported_claims: - The abstract overstates the conclusiveness of the framework's ability to "set the solid foundation for the BlockDAG technology" without acknowledging limitations
relevant_body_sentences:
"MAXCORD-IFA outperforms PHANTOM to large extents, especially when the attack power is heavy." (p.11)
"The results of PHANTOM are sensitive to the value of parameter k which is difficult to be determined for a given dataset." (p.11)
"This study is the first work on the MaxCord framework." (p.12)

filename: Yu et al. - 2018 - Internet of Things security and privacy-preserving method through nodes differentiation, concrete cl.pdf
filepath: /Users/v/solomonresearch/blockchain sna litrev/PDFs/Yu et al. - 2018 - Internet of Things security and privacy-preserving method through nodes differentiation, concrete cl.pdf
abstract_text:
Now, the security and privacy-preserving of Internet of Things are receiving more attention. This article proposes a new
method of Internet of Things security and privacy preserving by combining differentiated nodes, precision clustering,
RSA, multi-signature, and blockchain. To calculate the node rank value in Internet of Things, the number of nodes’ links
is taken as the weight of nodes based on PageRank. This method increases the node rank values’ difference between
nodes. Accurate clustering...
findings:
- DNK-Means algorithm effectively distinguishes between active and inactive nodes in IoT networks (p.11-12)
- RSA encryption shows lower latency compared to DES+ECDSA for encryption/decryption and signature verification (p.11-12)
- The proposed method protects IoT privacy through multi-signature, RSA encryption and blockchain while optimizing resource consumption (p.13)
- Storing encrypted data rather than raw data on blockchain reduces storage overhead (p.13)
- Using multi-signatures only for active nodes reduces time and space consumption (p.13)
gaps:
- Need for privacy protection methods that balance security and resource consumption in IoT (p.2)
- Lack of approaches combining node differentiation and blockchain for IoT security (p.2-3)
- Need for methods to handle dynamic IoT structures that change over time (p.14)
- Limited data transfer capacity on blockchain needs to be addressed (p.14)
methodologies:
- DNK-Means algorithm combining PageRank and k-means clustering (p.6-8)
- RSA encryption for data security (p.8-9)
- 2/3 multi-signature scheme for transaction verification (p.8-10)
- Blockchain for secure data transmission (p.9-10)
- Experimental validation using 20,000x20,000 random matrix (p.10)
limitations:
- Only considers static IoT structures, not dynamic changes over time (p.14)
- Limited data transfer capacity on blockchain (p.14)
- Only protects second layer of IoT architecture, not bottom sensor layer (p.2-3)
- Resource constraints still exist despite optimizations (p.13)

- "This article proposes a new method of Internet of Things security and privacy preserving by combining differentiated nodes, precision clustering, RSA, multi-signature, and blockchain."
- "To calculate the node rank value in Internet of Things, the number of nodes' links is taken as the weight of nodes based on PageRank."

"DNK-Means effectively filters out active nodes and inactive nodes, which reduces the consumption of time and space for subsequent steps" (p.13)

filename: Zhang et al. - 2024 - GraphTranslator Aligning Graph Model to Large Language Model for Open-ended Tasks.pdf
filepath: /Users/v/solomonresearch/blockchain sna litrev/PDFs/Zhang et al. - 2024 - GraphTranslator Aligning Graph Model to Large Language Model for Open-ended Tasks.pdf
abstract_text:
Large language models (LLMs) like ChatGPT, exhibit powerful
zero-shot and instruction-following capabilities, have catalyzed a
revolutionary transformation across diverse fields, especially for
open-ended tasks. While the idea is less explored in the graph
domain, despite the availability of numerous powerful graph mod-
els (GMs), they are restricted to tasks in a pre-defined form. Al-
though several methods applying LLMs to graphs have been pro-
posed, they fail to simultaneously handle the pre...
findings:
- Developed GraphTranslator framework to align graph models with LLMs for both pre-defined and open-ended tasks (p.1-2)
- Achieved better performance than baselines on zero-shot node classification tasks across multiple datasets (p.6-7)
- Demonstrated strong capabilities in graph question answering through both quantitative and qualitative analysis (p.7-8)
- Two-stage training strategy proved effective for bridging graph embeddings and LLM understanding (p.11)
gaps:
- Existing methods either use LLMs just to enhance node features or as standalone predictors, but fail to handle both pre-defined and open-ended tasks simultaneously (p.1-2)
- Significant modality gap exists between pre-trained graph models and LLMs that needs bridging (p.2)
- Lack of natural alignment data between node embeddings and textual descriptions (p.2)
methodologies:
- Producer module to construct alignment data through LLM-based description generation (p.3-4)
- Translator module with query tokens to convert node embeddings to LLM token space (p.4)
- Two-stage training approach: GM-text alignment followed by GM-LLM alignment (p.5)
- Evaluation through zero-shot classification and graph QA tasks (p.6-8)
limitations:
- Producer module quality heavily impacts overall Translator performance (p.10)
- Limited to using ChatGLM2-6B rather than larger LLMs due to resource constraints (p.10)
- Lack of comprehensive evaluation datasets and metrics for open-ended tasks (p.10)
- Current implementation may not capture all topology information encoded in node embeddings (p.10)
abstract_supported_sentences:
- "To break this dilemma, we propose to bridge the pretrained GM and LLM by a Translator, named GraphTranslator"
- "Extensive results demonstrate the effectiveness of our proposed GraphTranslator on zero-shot node classification"
- "The graph question answering experiments reveal our GraphTranslator potential across a broad spectrum of open-ended tasks"
abstract_unsupported_claims: - The abstract could better acknowledge the limitations around Producer module quality and evaluation metrics
relevant_body_sentences:
- "Our GraphTranslator achieves better performance than most of baselines, which indicates GM can greatly benefit from LLMs within our GraphTranslator" (p.7)
- "The experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of GraphTranslator on zero-shot node classification" (p.8)
- "Only provided unseen node embedding as prompt for LLM, our GraphTranslator gets 210 A in total, showcasing strong performance comparable to Vanilla LLM" (p.8)

The abstract generally provides an accurate high-level summary of the paper's key contributions and findings. The main claims around bridging graph models with LLMs and demonstrating effectiveness on both classification and QA tasks are well-supported by experimental results. However, the abstract could better acknowledge some key limitations around evaluation metrics and Producer module dependencies that are discussed in the paper body.

findings:
- Blockchain technology has been adopted in agri-food value chains in four main areas: traceability, information security, manufacturing and sustainable water management (p.11-15)
- Six key challenges identified: storage capacity/scalability, privacy leakage, high cost, regulation issues, throughput/latency, and lack of skills (p.15-18)
- Most blockchain applications are still in conceptual phase with limited empirical validation (p.19)

- Integration of blockchain with IoT and edge computing shows promise but faces technical challenges (p.21-22)
gaps:

methodologies:

filename: Zhou and Lee - 2021 - A Study on Blockchain Interoperability Mechanism.pdf
filepath: /Users/v/solomonresearch/blockchain sna litrev/PDFs/Zhou and Lee - 2021 - A Study on Blockchain Interoperability Mechanism.pdf
findings:
- Proposed a TCP-like cross-chain transport protocol (CCTP) for homogeneous blockchain interoperability (p.138-140)
- Developed a relay chain solution for heterogeneous blockchain interoperability using Merkle trees and state transition verification (p.140-143)
- Identified key requirements for blockchain interoperability: message authenticity, routing, validity proof, execution receipt, and single execution guarantee (p.136-137)
gaps:
- Lack of standard solution for cross-chain interoperation (p.127)
- Limited theoretical progress on blockchain interoperability (p.127, p.129)
- No uniform standards or successful use cases in production (p.129)
- Need for better security and efficiency in existing cross-chain technologies (p.131)
methodologies:
- Hash list and Merkle tree data structures for data validation (p.131-132)
- Light client verification approach (p.132-133)
- Simple Payment Verification (SPV) protocol (p.134)
- Modular layering architecture separating cross-chain functions from consensus (p.138)
- Message queue hash chains for state tracking (p.142-143)
limitations:
- Security and efficiency must be sacrificed for cross-chain interoperability (p.127)
- Implementation process is complex and difficult (p.129)
- Cross-chain efficiency depends heavily on single-chain standardization (p.129)
- No large-scale commercial applications yet (p.144)
- Solutions proposed are theoretical and need further exploration of implementation details (p.144)
abstract_supported_sentences:
- "Currently, there is no standard solution for cross-chain interoperation, and also little theoretical progress on this topic"
- "For homogeneous blockchains, we suggest a TCP-like cross-chain transport protocol (CCTP)"
- "For heterogeneous blockchains, we present a method to construct the relay chain to realize the cross-chain function"
- "Cross-chain interoperation itself breaks the completeness of the blockchain, therefore, some efficiency and safety must sacrifice to trade-off"
abstract_unsupported_claims:
- The claim about "60,000 blockchain projects" is not substantiated in the paper body
- The statement about covering "almost all aspects of our daily life" is an exaggeration without evidence
relevant_body_sentences:
"The essence of cross-chain is to transfer the message M on chain A safely and reliably to chain B, meanwhile reach the expected effect on chain B" (p.136)
"We can achieve this through a TCP-like handshake protocol by changing the status of cross-chain messages and transaction proofs to indirectly synchronize the state of the source chain and destination chain" (p.138)
"To realize cross-chain interoperation on heterogeneous blockchain equivalence to construct a blockchain covering the source chain and destination chain, this chain is commonly known as a relay chain" (p.141)

findings:
- The proposed GrNLFA model achieves higher prediction accuracy compared to baseline models, with 3.97% and 3.26% lower RMSE than M1 and M2 respectively (p. 5)
- The model significantly improves computational efficiency, reducing time consumption by 99.9% compared to baseline models (p. 5)
- Small values of the time slice parameter θ negatively affect prediction accuracy (p. 4)
- The model demonstrates stable performance across different cryptocurrency transaction networks (p. 5)
gaps:
- Previous methods only apply to static cryptocurrency transaction networks, neglecting dynamic network evolution (p. 1)
- Existing approaches are computationally inefficient due to full matrix operations (p. 1)
- Past research ignores that cryptocurrency transaction data are non-negative (p. 1)
methodologies:
- Graph regularized method to link past and future transactions (p. 2)
- Single latent factor-dependent, non-negative, multiplicative and graph regularized-incorporated update (SLF-NMGRU) algorithm (p. 2-3)
- Graph regularized nonnegative latent factor analysis (GrNLFA) model (p. 2-3)
- Root mean squared error (RMSE) and mean absolute error (MAE) for evaluation (p. 4)
limitations:
- Tensor methods could be explored to better express temporal network characteristics (p. 5)
- Model performance could be further optimized using second-order and momentum methods (p. 5)
- Current approach focuses only on link prediction, not other network analysis tasks (p. 1-2)

filename: Zhou et al. - 2023 - A Decentralized Federated Learning Based on Node Selection and Knowledge Distillation.pdf
filepath: /Users/v/solomonresearch/blockchain sna litrev/PDFs/Zhou et al. - 2023 - A Decentralized Federated Learning Based on Node Selection and Knowledge Distillation.pdf
findings:
- Proposed decentralized federated learning method achieves ~20-21% shorter training time while only sacrificing ~5% model accuracy compared to blockchain approach (p. 14)
- Method achieves model accuracy of 87.59%, 91.36%, and 89.15% on MNIST, CIFAR-10, and FEMNIST datasets respectively after 50 rounds under IID conditions (p. 9)
- Running times reduced by 20%, 21%, and 21% respectively on three datasets compared to blockchain-based decentralized training with 30% node selection (p. 13)
- Knowledge distillation mechanism helps achieve lower losses: ~0.08 on MNIST, ~0.03 on CIFAR-10, ~0.04 on FEMNIST (p. 11-12)
gaps:
- Need for efficient methods to obtain optimal nodes in complex/dynamic network environments (p. 2)
- Lack of solutions for unstable model training in decentralized federated learning due to noise and data bias (p. 2)
- Need to address high communication burden in federated learning with increasing model complexity (p. 5)
methodologies:
- Node selection mechanism based on local model performance and dataset size metrics (p. 6-7)
- Knowledge distillation using teacher-student model structure (p. 5-6)
- Decentralized architecture with variable central node selection (p. 3-4)
- Experiments on MNIST, CIFAR-10, and FEMNIST datasets under both IID and Non-IID settings (p. 8)
limitations:
- Not all nodes guaranteed to participate in each training round (p. 9)
- Some node results oscillate due to different network connection structures and data imbalance (p. 11)
- Slight decrease in accuracy compared to blockchain method under certain conditions (p. 9)
- Model accuracy reduced when fewer objects connected to network (p. 11)
abstract_supported_sentences:
- "To address this problem, this article proposed a decentralized federated learning method based on node selection and knowledge distillation."
- "The experiments were conducted on the public MNIST, CIFAR-10, and FEMNIST datasets for both the Independent Identically Distribution (IID) setting and the non-IID setting."
- "Numerical results show that the proposed method can achieve an improved accuracy as compared to the centralized federated learning method, and the computing time is reduced greatly"
abstract_unsupported_claims: - The abstract does not explicitly quantify the trade-off between accuracy loss and computation time reduction
relevant_body_sentences:
"Specifically, the method achieves a shorter training time by approximately 20%, 21%, and 21% while only sacrificing about 5% of the model accuracy." (p. 14)
"The proposed method achieves 81.18% model accuracy after 50 rounds of training." (p. 11)
"With the increase in the number of iteration rounds, the method in this article can converge when the number of iteration rounds is less than 40 rounds, and the convergence speed is slightly better than the other three methods." (p. 11)

filename: Zwitter and Hazenberg - 2020 - Decentralized Network Governance Blockchain Technology and the Future of Regulation.pdf
filepath: /Users/v/solomonresearch/blockchain sna litrev/PDFs/Zwitter and Hazenberg - 2020 - Decentralized Network Governance Blockchain Technology and the Future of Regulation.pdf
abstract_supported_sentences: N/A (No abstract provided)
abstract_unsupported_claims: N/A (No abstract provided)
relevant_body_sentences:
"The aim of this study is to merge the literature on governance with social network theory, in order to conceptualize a new approach to governance: decentralized network governance." (p.2)

"We argue that the current dominant modes of governance are inadequate in understanding governance in the digital domain and are poorly equipped to conceptualize novel forms of governance such as decentralized autonomous organizations (DAOs)." (p.1)

"This paper consists of four sections. In the first section, the terms datafication and blockchain technology are introduced. In the second section, governance literature is reviewed and dominant modes of governance are conceptualized. In the third section, arguments are put forward concerning why these modes of governance are inadequate in terms of effectively governing the quasi-theoretical conceptions introduced by DLT and blockchain technology. The fourth section offers the first methodological clues for the analysis of network governance, based on social network analysis." (p.1-2)

The paper presents a well-structured theoretical argument for a new governance framework, though it would benefit from more empirical validation. The methodology combines literature review with conceptual development and limited case analysis. The key contribution is the proposed Mode 3 decentralized network governance framework.
